HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Producing Abroad Is Harming Recovery

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
FOR nearly 29 months, the nation has struggled through a recession and a weak recovery. That is a long struggle, a new form of hardship for many Americans, who are tantalized with incessant forecasts that a decisive upturn is about to happen. But as the months wear on, the dogged optimism detaches from reality.
 For starters, the forecasters seem not to grasp how much the American economy has deviated from the standard business cycle and the standard cures. A major reason for the deviation is the mobility of American companies, particularly the ease with which they now shift operations to China and India. "The wholesale movement of jobs and production overseas is handcuffing the recovery," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com. 
 In other downturns since World War II, the economy moved from healthy growth to contraction and back to healthy growth, all in less than two years. The downward swings were relatively easy to fix. The swings began when companies found themselves producing more goods and services than people bought. Inventories built up, particularly in manufacturing, and companies responded by cutting output until it was below demand. Rather than produce more, companies filled orders from stockpiles. As output declined, unemployment rose and wages stopped increasing. Capital spending also suffered. After all, why expand when the capacity to produce already exceeds demand?
But the damage did not last long. The Federal Reserve stepped in, cutting interest rates to encourage spending. Unemployment insurance, public spending, and sometimes tax cuts, helped resurrect demand. As spending picked up and inventories disappeared, prices began to rise, which encouraged more production. Hiring resumed, as did capital spending.
These various remedies are being used now, and there is some strength in spending. Yet inventories have failed to diminish, so prices, production, hiring and capital spending do not rise. 
The difficulty is that companies have a choice that was not as available in the last downturn 12 years ago. Rather than halt production at home, they shift it abroad to cut costs, particularly labor costs. They feel compelled to do this. If they did not, their competitors would upstage them with their own lower-cost, overseas production that takes away sales back home.
In the process, the mechanism for restoring our economy to healthy growth -- by reducing inventories and excess capacity -- fails to function properly. Inventories may seem to diminish when only "Made in America" is counted. But in the new global economy, what's made in America and what's made abroad both contribute to inventories and capacity. The total does not shrink, and the economy flounders month after month. 
Still, there is some relief. Super-low interest rates, mortgage refinancing, stepped-up military spending and some of the Bush tax cuts augur a temporary pop in economic growth. But temporary is the operative word. The more enduring pressure on the economy is downward, not upward. 
THE biggest beneficiary appears to be China. Abundant transportation has made China an ever-easier place for American companies to shift production of goods and services for sale in the market back home.
The nation's trade deficit, the excess of our imports over exports, has risen by 31 percent since the recession began in March 2001. The increase, totaling $114 billion, would add one percentage point to American economic growth -- enough to turn a weak recovery into a strong one -- if the rise in output were at home, not abroad. One-third of the total increase represents imports from China, Mr. Zandi says. Honing the figures, Steven S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, finds that China's total exports have tripled since 1994, and that 65 percent of the $244 billion increase comes from foreign companies in China.
"We are criticizing the Chinese as if they were cleaning our clock and the only part of China that is cleaning our clock is the part that we put there," Mr. Roach said.
What is to be done? If we do anything, we are likely to pressure the Chinese to float their currency. A floating yuan would rise against the dollar, making Chinese exports more costly in the United States. Pressure is already coming from Congress for the Bush administration to negotiate the float.
We could also force American companies, through regulations, to stay out of countries that fail to observe minimal labor and environmental standards. Regulation is not popular in America. But it could regain its popularity, if the alternative is a continual loss of jobs in every state.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Dealing With Addiction, and What Comes After

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS

 BODY:
ADDICTION costs corporate America billions of dollars a year in lost productivity, absenteeism and higher health care expenses. It also derails many once-promising careers.
 More companies are willing to offer assistance these days, especially as they deal with higher levels of employee stress from heightened workloads and job cuts. Yet many workers are still reluctant to take advantage of this help, for fear of jeopardizing their positions. 
 "Telling something so personal would have lessened my authority as a leader," said a 65-year-old executive of a computer company in Philadelphia who recently returned from 28 days of treatment for alcoholism. "As a manager, you have to create some distance between you and your employees." The executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, had arranged for the treatment himself at the Caron Foundation, a rehabilitation center in Wernersville, Pa. 
He says his job has been business as usual since his return last spring, but he acknowledged making up a story about his extended absence, which he even gave to his boss. "I told them I was overstressed and my doctor asked me to rest for a month," he said.
Professionals in similar situations have many delicate issues to navigate. How, forexample, can they avoid being stigmatized by colleagues? And how can they explain gaps on a resume after a long treatment period?
Many employees who receive treatment -- whether for alcoholism or for drug, gambling or food addictions -- will undoubtedly have some difficulties in the beginning, experts say, but as they recover, so too will their careers.
Abuse of some drugs has been climbing in the workplace. According to Quest Diagnostics, which provides workplace drug tests, the number of workers and job applicants who tested positive for amphetamine use rose 17 percent in 2002 from the previous year. At the Waismann Institute, in Beverly Hills, Calif., 60 percent of the patients, mostly high-powered business people, are addicted to painkillers like OxyContin and Vicodin, up from about 10 percent four years ago, according to Dr. Clifford A. Bernstein, the medical director there.
Given the weakness in the economy and the job market, none of this surprises Dr. Kenneth Siegel, a psychologist and president of the Impact Group, an executive leadership consulting firm in Beverly Hills. In the economic downturn of the late 1980's and early 1990's, he said, "Valium suddenly become the most prescribed drug in America." Similarly, today's workers are seeking ways to curb their anxieties and depression, he said.
"I don't think you're going to find a lot of C.E.O.'s smoking pot or snorting cocaine in the company restroom," Dr. Siegel said, "but we are seeing executives abusing alcohol and popping prescription drugs."
One of the biggest difficulties is seeking help in the first place. Managers may be surrounded by underlings who are more than willing to help cover up the problem. A recent survey by the Caron Foundation of its patients found that 75 percent of executives in recovery said they had secretaries or assistants who went to great lengths to cover for them. Ninety percent said their peers had to work extra hours to compensate for their addiction.
Bruce Cotter, a recovering alcoholic, said that when he was a sales executive for major television networks on the East Coast during the 1980's, his assistants would routinely reschedule his appointments and even compile his sales reports. "I had a whole army of people who would mop up my messes," he said. Mr. Cotter now runs Bruce W. Cotter & Associates in Butler, Md., which intervenes on behalf of companies to provide treatment for addicted executives.
Another issue is confidentiality. Many workers, particularly executives, hesitate to seek help through their company's employee assistance programs or human resources departments, out of fear of looking weak or even harming the company's reputation.
"They feel that their company doesn't need to have the burden of knowing their top V.P., or C.E.O., is having a problem," said Dr. Scott C. Stacy, clinical program director for the Professional Renewal Center in Lawrence, Kan., which treats executives for substance and behavioral problems, including gambling and sexual addiction.
To help make executives feel more comfortable about seeking help, some companies are offering programs that promise heightened confidentiality, according to Dr. Richard A. Chaifetz, chief executive of the ComPsych Corporation in Chicago. ComPsych provides employee assistance programs to companies like General Electric, American Express and Sprint. Meanwhile, Resources for Living in Austin, Tex., whose clients include Wal-Mart and Bridgestone, has a substance-abuse counseling program that can be completed entirely by phone.
William P. Schurgin, a partner at the Seyfarth Shaw law firm in Chicago, says employers are generally under no obligation to keep workers with untreated substance-abuse problems on the payroll. The Americans With Disabilities Act, he noted, does not protect these employees. But he added that employers were much more likely to support those who request help rather than those whose problems were discovered through drug testing or other means. "Most companies are going to give you a second chance," he said.
After seeking help, patients should avoid trying to keep up workloads during treatment.
"That's not the time to focus on work," said Dennis Henning, a consultant in Camarillo, Calif. who helps addicted lawyers and executives in the entertainment industry receive help through an intervention program. Mr. Henning, who is himself recovering from an eating disorder, said he recently worked with a lawyer who would have co-workers sneak in work for him to do.
MR. COTTER said that he, too, had confiscated executives' cellphones and laptops after they entered a treatment center. "These people want to keep their careers on track, and so they don't feel like they can take a moment out for themselves," he said. "But I have to convince them that if they don't get help, their career -- not to mention their lives -- might end up in the toilet."
Career experts also warn against trying to do too much soon after returning to work.
"A lot of executives who return to work are so fearful of losing their jobs, especially in this economy, that they step up the pace of their work and don't take vacations, or even lunch breaks," said Ruth Luban, a psychotherapist based in Santa Monica, Calif. She suggests easing back into the workload, perhaps even working part time for a few weeks if possible. Once the person is back to a full-time schedule, he should set boundaries on the job, by taking time out for lunch each day, for example, she said. 
Reduced work schedules -- or even lunch breaks -- are not always possible for those who are feeling the pressure of work. Ms. Luban said she was working with a lawyer who recently was treated for a drug addiction and was about to return to work at a company that was merging with another concern. "There's only so much slack they can give him," she said.
She advised him to carve out tiny, regular portions in each day, so that he could "at least take a few deep breaths" without his bosses noticing.
IT'S up to the employee to decide whether to explain an absence for treatment to curious colleagues, said Liz Ryan, a human resources consultant in Boulder, Colo. Like the computer company executive from Pennsylvania who was treated for alcoholism, many of her clients chalk up the absence to an unspecified illness. But in some instances, she said, a recovering addict may need the support of a few trusted co-workers.
She said she recently worked with a salesman, a recovering alcoholic, whose boss had kept pressuring him to have a few beers with clients at late-night gatherings.
"He would really egg him on," she said. "Finally, the salesman had to clue in his boss, who was very understanding. If a boss or co-workers aren't supportive, by all means, look for a new opportunity." 
In some cases, of course, colleagues may know about a worker's problem before treatment is sought. Ms. Ryan once worked with a young woman who returned from a work outing so intoxicated that she passed out in the office in front of several employees. Shortly thereafter, she entered an alcohol recovery program. When she returned, Ms. Ryan recommended that she simply acknowledge to co-workers that she had dealt with the problem and was ready to move on.
"People have short attention spans," she said. "Once they see you're back and you're doing a good job, they'll lose interest."
Experts recommend that recovering addicts seek out support groups set up exclusively for executives or certain professionals. The groups can help deal with worries about attendance at cocktail parties, for example, or other networking events.
Other career concerns can be addressed in the groups. The Pennsylvania executive said he was involved in a therapy group made up of high-level executives. For three one-hour sessions a week, the members talked about how their careers had contributed to their addiction problems and gave one another tips on eliminating some of the biggest stresses from their jobs.
"All of a sudden, I felt like I wasn't alone anymore," he said.
Career experts recommend that job seekers not disclose past addiction problems to prospective employers in an interview. "Let's be realistic -- there's still somewhat of a stigma to saying that you're an addict," Ms. Ryan said.
She advises job seekers to carefully develop a speech that explains any resume gaps, and to practice it repeatedly. "Be prepared to say something like, 'I was resolving some health issues,' or 'I was doing some personal development work,' " she said. 
"Most hiring managers won't bat an eyelash at a three- or even six-month gap, especially in this economy."

HEADLINE: Smiling Through the 30th, A Birthday Once Apocalyptic 

BYLINE:  By VANESSA GRIGORIADIS

 BODY:
BY all accounts, Alison Zuker, an advertising creative director, is a very social person. This year, however, her calendar has been particularly cluttered -- not with weddings, baby showers or job promotion parties, but with celebrations of that once maligned milepost, the 30th birthday.
 Perched on a wooden bench at the Porch, a bar on a newly gentrified stretch of Avenue C, during a party for her friend Eli Wolf, an executive at Blue Note Records, Ms. Zuker estimated that she had been to two dozen such parties this year. "Easy," she said, crossing her legs. "In fact, some nights I'd hit three." 
 Once, turning 30 was slightly irritating, an embarrassing passage, and people were in no mood to broadcast the news. This was especially true for unmarried women and for men whose careers had not yet ignited. 
Today, when marriage is routinely delayed past 30 and the 20's are often an extended adolescence -- a time of romantic and professional hopscotch -- a 30th birthday feels to many the way 21 once did, as the gateway to the more serious adult world. It is no longer a day to count up regrets stoically, but to pop the Moet & Chandon. Increasingly, it is celebrated with all the pomp of a graduation blowout or a wedding reception, with formal invitations, speeches, rented halls or yachts, and guest lists drawn from every stage of the person's life.
"People have been treating 30's as bar mitzvahs, Sweet 16's or -- dare I say it? -- weddings," Ms. Zuker said.
With the years between college graduation and marriage stretching into the double digits, many yearn for a new rite of passage to fill the gap, and the Big Three-Oh has taken on this role. Ms. Zuker has recently attended a party lasting a weekend in Las Vegas, an "over the hill" gathering where the dress code was black but the atmosphere jovial, and celebrations with a "dirty 30" theme featuring visits tostrip clubs. Several friends included R.S.V.P. cards with their invitations or had memory books prominently placed for guests to record their thoughts.
Greg Clayman, a founder of Upoc, a mobile technology company in New York, sent out invitations (the cover showed one of his baby pictures ) to 600 people for his 30th. "It was an amazing retrospective, shall we say, of everyone I've known," Mr. Clayman said. "Even my doctor came."
Ms. Zuker, whose own birthday party was at the mod Lower East Side bar 17 Home in late June, said she had invited "equal amounts of people from ages 0 to 5, 6 to 18, college, after college and work."
"It wasn't, like, let's just send out an e-vite," said Ms. Zuker, who wore a red halter top and dashed around the room as if it were a networking event. "It was very, very strategic."
As Dan McAdams, a professor of psychology and human development at Northwestern University, sees it, "Thirty may signal more than it used to -- that you're really a full-fledged adult -- because people in contemporary modern life live differently in their 20's than they used to."
"The 20's are now a time of continued exploration and experimentation," Professor McAdams said. "People hedge their bets the way one used to in adolescence."
Turning 30 may have lost its stigma because expectations of one's 20's are so different from what they were a generation ago, experts say. In her best-selling 1976 book, "Passages: Predictable Crises of Adult Life," Gail Sheehy defined 30 as the beginning of midlife.
"During the 20's," she wrote, "when a man gains confidence by leaps and bounds, a married woman is usually losing the superior assurances she once had as an adolescent."
Betsy Carter, once the editor of My Generation, a former baby-boomer magazine that was published by AARP, recalled that when she turned 30 in 1975 she did not go to a single 30th-birthday party, "including my own."
"At that age" she said, "a lot of things were just beginning. You were married or pregnant, and you didn't need another reason to throw a party."
In an interview, Ms. Sheehy recalled: "When I was 29, I told people I was 30 just so I had a year to deal with it. People used to suffer in silence." Now, Ms. Sheehy added, a 30th-birthday party is a "showcase" of sorts "for those women making no bones about being single."
"Thirty," she said, "is the new 22."
Party planners and suppliers report a rising demand for 30th-birthday celebrations with all the trimmings.
"I get more requests for 30th-birthday cakes than 40ths at this point," said Edie Connolly, an owner of Cakes n' Shapes on West 39th Street.
Francesa Abbracciamento, an event planner in Manhattan, said: "With the economy the way it is, there's been a departure from corporate events, and the replacement is more private parties. And 30's a big one."
And while fewer people are turning 30 now than in the generation before them, Hallmark's sales of 30th-birthday cards have remained steady in recent years.
Mori Ninomiya, a founder of Take Out Marketing in New York, invited hundreds to his 30th birthday on July 10 at Double Happiness, a bar on Mott Street.
For her 30th in June, Selma Nasser, a publicist, celebrated both her birthday and her Middle Eastern heritage with a theme party for 90 at Soho House, the private club in the meatpacking district. She hired a belly dancer, screened "Lawrence of Arabia" and offered around a drink named "the Sheik Selma," made with freshly squeezed guava juice and vodka.
"It was really fun," Ms. Nasser said, "although apparently the Sheik Selma hurt a lot of people the next day."
In the last quarter-century, nearly everything about one's 20's has changed. Young people are living at home longer, experiencing a far longer period of job instability, marrying and having children later and staying in school longer.
Nationally, the average age of women at their first marriage was 25.3 last year, the highest ever, according to the Census Bureau; for men it was 26.9, the second-highest on record. In New York City, with its large numbers of well-educated professionals, the proportion of single people over 30 is especially high: 41.5 percent of those age 30 to 34 have never married, according to 2000 census data analyzed by the sociology department at Queens College.
"Thirty is where 25 was 40 or 50 years ago," said Frank Furstenberg, chairman of the MacArthur Network on Adult Transitions in Chicago.
"The main reason," he said, "is the growing demands of a skill-based economy," which prompts young people to live longer with their parents while they earn advanced degrees or save for a home. 
According to census data analyzed by American Demographics magazine, 15 percent of unmarried men and 8 percent of unmarried women 25 to 34 lived at home in 1998, compared with 9 percent of men and 7 percent of women in 1970.
A simple explanation for why the perception of the 30th birthday is changing, said Matti Gershenfeld, a psychologist in Jenkintown, Pa., is that people live longer. The life expectancy of a male born in 2000 was 74.1 at birth, and of a female, 79.5 -- compared with 46.3 for males and 48.3 for females born in 1900. "So 30 isn't the midpoint in your life, much less middle-aged," Ms. Gershenfeld said.
Jill Grigsby, a professor of sociology at Pomona College in Claremont, Calif., said, "There are people now who think they're not middle-aged until they're 60."
Blake Bhatia would agree. "I always viewed life in three stages, or trimesters," said Mr. Bhatia, a technology entrepreneur in New York who celebrated his 30th birthday last month by chartering a yacht for 130 guests. "The first 30 years of your life is your childhood, the next 30 years your adulthood, and from 60 and hopefully till 90, your golden years."
Mr. Bhatia, who received a Rolex watch from his mother and cash from other family members, followed his yacht dinner with a party at a Chelsea restaurant and a weekend gathering at his house in the Hamptons. (Total cost of the celebration: $25,000 to $30,000.) He addressed the gathering with a 45-minute speech reflecting on the good times he had had with friends, many of them present, from his toddler years to now.
As with Mr. Bhatia, Ms. Zuker's priority on her birthday was celebrating herself. Although she had made it clear to her boyfriend that she was in no hurry to have a ring, she received a Tiffany box from him on her 30th. "I was opening the package -- like, 'What is this now?' " Ms. Zuker said. It turned out to be a large crystal paperweight. "He was, like, 'I got you the biggest diamond that Tiffany's had,' " she said. "Then he kept asking: 'Is it big enough? Is it big enough?' He thought that was really funny." 
Although women at this age generally express a desire to hold out for Mr. Right, not all the traditional anxiety at being 30 and single has dissipated.
"It's not all rah-rah," said Stephanie Deutsch, a New York Web producer who turned 30 on May 20. "There's certainly societal pressure to be with someone at this age. My grandparents are asking about children."
Ms. Deutsch chose to celebrate her birthday as an occasion for female bonding: she had dinner with 14 girlfriends and 6 women from her family, including her grandmother. Speeches were made, and each guest took home a vase filled with fresh roses.
"I was single for a really long time, and I felt that I wanted to be surrounded by all the women in my life," Ms. Deutsch said. "Thirty is a big deal, or at least it is to me, and I wanted to be with the people who've supported me on my journey getting older." Ms. Deutsch's boyfriend, brother and father were allowed in only during the dessert course.
Turning 30 has become the new "threshold age of adulthood," said Jeffrey Arnett, a professor at the University of Maryland and the author of "Emerging Adulthood: The Winding Road From the Late Teens Through the Twenties," to be published next year by Oxford University Press. "Instead of social transitions like marriage and parenthood," he said, "people now define themselves as adults by individual markers. Adulthood is about accepting responsibility, making individual decisions and becoming financially independent."
"By age 30," he added, "the majority of people think they've reached adulthood, whereas before then people think of themselves as not quite there."
Last Sunday night, about 50 friends gathered to celebrate with Ahna Tessler, a comedian, at a humid apartment hung with white streamers in Chinatown. Kazoos were stacked on end tables. Before Ms. Tessler blew out the 30 candles on her chocolate cake, Frank Sinatra sang "I Did It My Way" from the stereo.
Ms. Tessler had required her guests, a group of actors, writers and comedians rarely seen out of jeans, to dress up -- cocktail dresses for the women and suits, or at least ties, for the men.
"I just bought this off the street for $4," said Matt Hyams, gesturing to his striped tie.
He stood with Mark Alhadeff, an actor, who was wearing a heavy blue suit.
"A girl has a 30th birthday, and you date her best friend, and so you end up in a suit," said Mr. Alhadeff, dabbing sweat from his forehead.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
Want to Stop the Conversation? Just Mention Your Finances

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THIS summer, I rented a beach house with four friends in Sag Harbor on Long Island. It's a great old place with hardwood floors, window seats and a patio overlooking the water. We all work in the publishing industry and spendmany hours discussing our jobs, love lives, plastic surgery and politics -- everything except, strangely, money.
 Sure, we talk about dividing our purchases evenly and reimbursing one another, but no one discusses salary, savings or how much is owed on the Visa card. 
 "Talking about your love life is light and entertaining, but it's rude to ask how much someone makes," said Leigh Gallagher, 30, one of my housemates and a reporter at Forbes magazine.
Financial etiquette seems to vary by geography and, to some extent, the condition of the economy. I have found that in New York, it may be unacceptable to talk about income, but that it is often O.K. to ask someone how much they pay in rent or maintenance. Such questions may be considered crass elsewhere. People I know in parts of Europe and Latin America say it is common for friends to ask one another about their economic status. And during the dot-com heyday, many people traded stock option information like baseball cards; talking about money was part of the culture. 
"I think it goes back to my parents who were raised in the Depression, and for them money is an off-limits subject," said Lowell Jaffe, 38, the chief executive of New World Traders, a fashion accessories manufacturer based in Chicago, of his reluctance to discuss financial matters. "I have a much easier time talking about anything -- you name it -- than money." 
From my own childhood, I recall my mother taking me to see a rather racy film, "Animal House," but refusing to talk about our household income.
"It wasn't your concern," she told me recently. "As long as the child's needs are met emotionally and financially, there's no reason to discuss family finances. I never thought of asking my own father what he made."
Point taken. But I always wanted to know if we were rich. (I was told that we were "comfortable.")
Some celebrities and political figures who come from modest means are happy to share their struggles; it makes their triumphs that much more pronounced. But if you come from a well-to-do family, lips are usually firmly sealed. 
"Talking about your experience with money is, at a very deep level, talking about where you came from, who you are now, what kind of person you ultimately want to be, what kind of relationships you value and where you find meaning in life," said Pamela York Klainer, a workplace consultant and the author of "How Much is Enough? Harness the Power of Your Money Story -- and Change Your Life" (Basic Books).
"Money is a very tangible expression of what you do and what you really care about," she said. "Talking about your experience of money has everything to do with how you understand professional success, and with whether you can allow yourself to be happy."
Frankly, I'd be in big trouble if my self-worth were wrapped up in my net worth. That could explain why I've never really minded talking about my financial situation: my salary isn't significant enough to be newsworthy, although I do feel a sense of pride for having been able to survive for several years in New York as a freelance writer.
My brother, Ray, a comedian, is equally candid about his income. But our sister, Hillary, who works in Silicon Valley, says, "Showing off one's fancy car, P.D.A. with integrated MP3 player, summer house, or throwing an elaborate party, is a classier way of communicating monetary status."
Dr. York Klainer says Americans, over all, are far too secretive about money topics.
"Money is an ordinary part of life; we use it more than we eat, pray or have sex," she said. "The way we learn anything and become sophisticated is by talking about it."
CANDACE BAHR, a co-founder of the Women's Institute for Financial Education (www.wife.org) a nonprofit organization, agreed. Ms. Bahr is also a co-founder of the Money Club (www.moneyclubs.com), which helps establish support groups for women who want to take control of their financial lives. Members discuss their financial aspirations and pitfalls and help one another plan for the future. There are 43 clubs around the country.
"I had just gotten myself out of $17,000 in debt and wanted to not end up there again when I found out about the Money Club," said Maru Corrada, an interior redesigner in her mid-30's who started a Money Club in her neighborhood of San Diego. "It's helped me a lot to talk to other people who are struggling with the same issues. It makes you feel less alone."
Here's what I say: From now on, when the subject of money comes up, embrace it. Discuss your debt. Acknowledge that your boss gave you only a small fraction of the raise you deserve, and that you are struggling to pay your rent. 
But if someone asks how much you weigh, run for the hills.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
An Assortment of Advice, but at What Price?

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH REED SMITH

 BODY:
ALAN M. JACOBSEN says he became concerned that his financial adviser was more interested in earning high commissions than in protecting his investments.
 On top of annual account maintenance fees averaging 1.3 percent of the $350,000 in his portfolio, Mr. Jacobsen said that over the five years of his investment he paid an additional $12,000, including sales charges on mutual funds and fees associated with a high-cost variable annuity. 
 "The costs were really driving us nuts," said Mr. Jacobsen, 64, who lives in Waterloo, Iowa, with his wife, Judith. So, in the summer of 2000, he severed ties with American Express Financial Advisors and with Terry Kuntz, his adviser there. He switched to Jon A. Ford, an independent financial adviser in Cedar Falls, Iowa, who charges an annual fee of 1 percent of the value of his portfolio, with no additional costs. 
Mr. Kuntz and American Express declined to comment about Mr. Jacobsen's complaints, but David E. Kanihan, a spokesman for the company, said, "We have never been about trying to make money off clients in the short term." 
In recent years, many people have become angry about the cost of investing through stockbrokers, who often bear the titles of financial advisers or financial consultants. The widespread adoption of these titles confuses some consumers, who are unable to "differentiate among the blurring traditional channel segments of the advice market," according to a recent study by Cerulli Associates, a Boston consulting firm.
Investors should understand that their interests aren't always aligned with those of financial advisers, particularly those employed by big brokerage firms, said Barbara L. Roper, director of investor protection at the Consumer Federation of America. 
"While I do think the big houses have changed somewhat in the way they do business, in the end these are still primarily salespeople who are marketing themselves as advisers," she said. It's important, she added, to remember that advisers at large firms "are ultimately beholden to their employers."
Most small investors can manage quite well on their own with no-load mutual funds, Ms. Roper said. Those who feel they need help, she added, would be better off using independent financial advisers whose income comes solely from fees -- not commissions.
Large Wall Street brokerage firms say their fees are fair and straightforward, and that their analytical resources far outstrip the capabilities of any independent financial planner. In the last five years, the brokerage firms have generally moved away from relying primarily on commissions and now charge most customers annual fees based on assets under management. These fees generally range from 1 to 3 percent of assets.
Brokerage firms typically charge lower percentages for larger portfolios and are often willing to negotiate terms with wealthier clients. The smaller an investor's portfolio, however, the less flexibility he is likely to have in negotiating compensation with a broker.
In return, the brokers set up investment strategies and often offer tax management, estate and retirement planning and advice on college savings plans. While asset-based fees generally cover most direct costs borne directly by the investor, additional commissions are sometimes charged. And many advisers collect additional sales commissions from insurance firms, banks and mutual fund companies.
Brokerage firms say they train their advisers to focus on a client's long-term interests. Mr. Kanihan, the spokesman for American Express Financial Advisors, who said he could not comment about Mr. Jacobsen's situation, said that the company wanted to "build long-term relationships with clients." 
At Merrill Lynch, the biggest brokerage firm, roughly 14,000 financial advisers rely mainly on asset-based fees, but they can earn commissions, depending on the arrangement with their clients, according to Erik Hendrickson, spokesman for Merrill. 
"What we say is there is no one right way in terms of the compensation structure," Mr. Hendrickson said. "It's up to the client and to the adviser to decide." Mr. Hendrickson added that Merrill takes measures to ensure that advisers are fair to clients. Fundamentally, he said, "financial advisers prosper as his or her clients prosper and as the number of prospering clients grows."
DENNY CUMMINGS, a Merrill financial adviser in Chicago, said that his clients' portfolios generally ranged from $5 million to $25 million each and that his annual fees averaged 1.1 percent of a portfolio's value. He said he preferred annual fees to commissions. "Commissions bring too much potential conflict, and even if there is no conflict, there is the perceived issue of conflict," he said.
Federal and state laws require that financial advisers try to avoid conflicts of interest and to disclose potential problems, said Robert E. Plaze, associate director of investment management at the Securities and Exchange Commission. But he said investors should understand that one way or another, they will have to pay for financial advice.
Fees can diminish long-term returns. Consider what happens to $100,000 invested in stock and bond funds yielding 8 percent over 20 years. Assuming that dividends are reinvested, the value compounds to $466,000 minus costs. When an investor pays an annual fee of 1 percent of the value of his portfolio, the investment loses $79,000, to $387,000. It plunges to $265,000 if annual expenses hit 3 percent. And that is before taxes and inflation are considered. 
"The single most important factor you can control, and the one that will have the greatest effect on your long-term success, is cost," Ms. Roper said. 
Excessive costs are one reason the S.E.C. began an investigation recently into the way brokerage firms sell mutual funds. In May, the S.E.C. chairman, William H. Donaldson, told a House Financial Services subcommittee that the agency would examine whether incentives at large firms push brokers to sell mutual funds that generate high commissions to customers, even though such investments may be unsuitable for them.
On July 10, the S.E.C. fined Prudential Securities $382,000 for failing to adequately supervise a broker who sold mutual fund shares that generated inappropriately high commissions. The S.E.C. and state regulators in New York and Massachusetts are investigating whether Morgan Stanley misled investors who bought its mutual funds. In a statement last week, Morgan Stanley acknowledged that it had paid its brokers higher commissions for selling its own funds. "Morgan Stanley supports enhanced disclosure in the fund industry and will continue to cooperate fully with various regulators," the firm said.
Charles Schwab, the big discount brokerage firm, says it keeps investors' costs low by charging fees for specific services, instead of imposing continuing annual fees for retaining an adviser, said Morrison Shafroth, a spokesman. For example, Schwab will balance an investor's portfolio once for $250. Schwab also refers investors with at least $250,000 in assets to affiliated independent advisory firms, which typically charge a fee of about 1 percent of assets. Not included in that fee are the costs of transactions through Schwab.
Investors can get information from the S.E.C. about financial advisers who manage more than $25 million in client assets. Those records are online at http://www.sec.gov/investor/brokers.htm.
Other advisers must register with state securities regulators. The North American Securities Administrators Association (http://www.nasaa.org/nasaa/abtnasaa/find_regulator.asp) provides investors with an online link to those state filings.
Ms. Roper suggested that consumers choose independent advisers through the National Association of Professional Financial Advisors (www.napfa.org), whose members earn their income solely from fees based on a percentage of managed assets.
Another group, the Financial Planning Association -- www.fpanet.org -- does not insist that its members adhere to this compensation structure. The Certified Financial Planner Board of Standards, which accredits financial planners, is another good source (www.cfp.net). It does not require its members to adhere to a specific compensation structure but monitors those who claim to limit themselves to fees from clients.
Sheryl D. Garrett, an independent financial adviser in Shawnee, Kan., said she charges clients $180 an hour, with no commissions, for a broad range of advice; clients then put her strategy into effect by themselves. 
Ms. Garrett said she began her career 16 years ago at a large firm. "I was miserable there because I couldn't just advise people on their investments," she said. "I was always under pressure to sell products."
John C. Bogle, founder of the Vanguard Group and a longtime critic of the financial services industry, says it is crucial to understand that the financial services sector is essentially sales driven. "Given their temperament and the nature of the profession, brokers and advisers are usually bullish," Mr. Bogle said. "The whole system depends on their ability to sell you things. So their integrity is tough to measure."

HEADLINE: Leaning on Their Parents, Again 

BYLINE:  By JENNIE GREEN

 BODY:
IN November 1999, Josh Maeir moved from Chicago to Sharon, Mass., so that his wife and two young sons could be closer to his in-laws. An experienced software engineer, Mr. Maeir took an upper-level management position at a company that makes materials testing equipment. A year later, he accepted a more challenging and lucrative opportunity at a start-up that designs traffic monitoring systems. 
 But by July 2002, the start-up's investment capital had been reduced by half, and Mr. Maeir was out of a job. 
 "I wasn't too worried in the beginning," said Mr. Maeir, who is 39. "But after three or four months we had burned through our savings and still nothing was happening. My wife is a stay-at-home mom. A year later, with unemployment running out, I can see the need to get a couple of 'bridge' jobs." 
He is now working as a bank teller and has applied for part-time sales jobs at RadioShack and Home Depot. He estimates that if he has two jobs, he will earn about $25,000 a year, including benefits, about one-third of his former income. Despite his predicament, his two sons, aged 3 and 6, continue to attend an independent day school, his wife continues to care for them and the family continues to live in a comfortable home.
Moreover, he has preserved the debt-free state in which he entered unemployment. For him, the solution is straightforward but not simple: he is among a growing number of mature professionals who receive financial assistance from parents, in-laws or both.
Figures are unavailable on the flow of dollars from 60-, 70- and 80-year-old Americans to their adult children who are unemployed or underemployed. But there appears to be an increase in the number of adults who depend on parents because of prolonged employment problems.
"I hear about it all the time," said Lisa Miller, executive director of Clear Connections, a networking and support center based in Dallas for displaced professionals. "Nowadays, our members are getting help not only from their parents, but also from their in-laws, brothers, sisters, aunts and uncles and cousins."
Niels H. Nielsen, author of "Princeton Management Consultants Guide to Your New Job" (John Wiley & Sons), agreed. He said that while many displaced workers received help from their parents, few would be willing to acknowledge it. 
"The underlying reality is that a lot of people are getting pretty desperate now," Mr. Nielsen said. "It also doesn't help that there's tremendous denial among information technology professionals about getting back to work in their field."
As of June, about nine million Americans were unemployed, or 6.4 percent of the work force, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. That compares with a rate of just 3.9 percent in October 2000.
For many white-collar workers, the periods of unemployment can be long. Last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, these workers accounted for 46.3 percent of all people who were unemployed for at least 27 weeks. Thatis up from 35.1 percent in 1997. 
If family dynamics can be complicated and bewildering when resources are plentiful, imagine how tension can escalate when finances dry up.
"It feels strange to become dependent after all these years," Mr. Maeir said. "It's not a situation that I ever would have imagined I'd be in -- especially not for so long. My mother and my in-laws help out because they can, because they're generous, and because they really care about us. But there are some strings. We were always careful about how we spent money. But now we feel self-conscious. Once, when we hired an electrician to fix a ceiling fan, it turned into this big deal because my in-laws considered it to be an extravagance." 
In more than a dozen interviews with people in their 30's, 40's and 50's who have accepted cash loans or gifts from their parents in the last few years, some patterns emerged. Unemployed adults who had functioned successfully in the workplace for many years all felt considerable shame about their new situations.
They know that they were laid off, not fired, but that didn't stop them from blaming themselves. "I am a 45-year-old man," said Steven Fields, a former systems administrator at Electronic Data Systems in Dallas. "I should be independent enough to pay my own rent. I feel so grateful to my dad for literally saving me from becoming homeless, but it's extremely hard on the self-esteem."
THE newly unemployed may rarely ask for help, even when bank balances dip into the single digits. When they do accept assistance, it tends to be with a combination of gratitude and hesitation. And they often fret over disappointing their parents, whom they imagine will encounter future hardship as a result of the generosity.
Unemployed professionals can have a hard time communicating with parents who have little or no firsthand experience with professional insecurity. Gordon Hatcher is a husband, father, and designer of custom telecommunications systems who says he was laid off from "the best job I ever had" -- at Sun Microsystems in Boston, in November 2002.
Just after he became unemployed, Mr. Hatcher's mother, a long-divorced college professor, started to send money, unsolicited, in what Mr. Hatcher described as a "pure and generous way." Mr. Hatcher said his father, who built missiles for the federal government at companies like Raytheon for 30 years, had a more negative perspective about the situation. "He couldn't understand why I didn't run out the day I became unemployed to find a job as an airport baggage checker or with the federal government," Mr. Hatcher said.
Richard Harris of Westborough, Mass., was happy to support his son, daughter-in-law and grandson, who live in San Francisco, for a year, but then he started to wonder if he was doing his son a disservice. "It's getting into quite a bit of money now," Mr. Harris said. "But I'm not worried about that. I worry now that my son is at risk of losing the confidence and independence that I enjoyed throughout my adult life." 
Mr. Harris said that when he told his son that he had decided to reduce his monthly allowance by 60 percent for six months, before he withdrew support altogether, his son understood. "I said to him, Andy, your life as you know it is over." Shortly thereafter, his son landed his first temporary job. 
For years, Karl Pillemer, a professor of human development at Cornell University, has studied relationships between aging parents and their adult offspring. When adult children have problems they seem to have brought on themselves, Professor Pillemer has found, their parents tend to become upset. When the adult children suffer from problems that don't seem to be of their own making -- like corporate layoffs -- the parents tend to feel more sympathy.
But only to a point. When unemployment continues for more than six months, the older generation starts to worry that something is wrong with the children. 
"Usually, unemployment isn't perceived as a problem until it goes on for a long time," Professor Pillemer said. "Only then do most parents worry that their children have stopped developing normally. The most important thing for any new parent to hear is that their baby is normal. This continues throughout the life cycle. At some point, most parents want to feel that their job is done -- that their children might even become a source of support for them in their old age."
OLDER people who decide to help their adult children often do so with ambivalence. Many professionals in their 60's and early 70's came of age in the post-Depression era, when working hard was insurance against unemployment. Some people from this generation may believe that an unemployed child who really wants a job can get one after a couple of weeks.
Others, like Joel Goldberg, who is Mr. Maeir's father-in-law and a certified public accountant with his own firm, are sorry that a high cost of living has coincided with the loss of a job. "I bought our home when the cost of a house was a couple of years' salary," Mr. Goldberg said. "It was easier to get set up back then. We raised our kids to be self-sufficient, so my daughter is quite unhappy now. Josh is also unhappy because he's an ambitious guy who wants to get out there and do something. It's a real boot in the tail to be unemployed, even if it's not your fault. So we try to be supportive; we try not to say anything that's going to make them feel worse. 
"On the other hand, it can get expensive. It's not a fortune, though. Heck, instead of buying a new car this year I can just fix the old one."
David Roane, physician in charge of geriatric psychiatry at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, says his patients have always talked about whether their adult children have achieved financial independence. "My sense is that it has less to do with resentment and more to do with them thinking about their own mortality, and how things are going to be when they approach the end of their lives," Dr. Roane said.
That leads to questions from parents about their adult children's choices in careers, spending and housing. When adult children become dependent after long periods of independence, many parents feel almost obligated to voice opinions they had previously kept to themselves. And that can lead to conflicts.
Aside from short-term unemployment benefits, few public resources are available to dislocated professionals who turn to family for support and struggle to redefine relationships and revise expectations. Economic independence is a condition that aging parents and their adult children are thought to aspire to naturally; it is also part of the collective American identity.
"Here in the United States," Professor Pillemer said, "intimacy at a distance is the ideal condition for relationships between parents and their adult offspring."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: William J. Nasgovitz And Eric J. Miller; 
Heartland Value Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
THE bull is out of the barn, say William J. Nasgovitz and Eric J. Miller, co-managers of the $1.02 billion Heartland Value fund, which specializes in small companies.
 The managers point to various signs that a bull market began in April: rising corporate profits in 2002, historically low interest rates and technical trading patterns that suggested that a market bottom had been reached and that stocks were on the way up. 
 The stocks of small companies are in their fourth year of outperforming bigger stocks. But small stocks "are coming off an incredibly depressed valuation base after the speculative excesses" of 1998 to 2000, Mr. Nasgovitz said from the managers' office in Milwaukee. 
Smaller companies are still much cheaper than big ones, Mr. Miller said. "We're finding scores of small-cap and microcap companies that are industry leaders but selling at half the market multiple or less," he added. 
The fund returned 17.3 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, placing in the top 6 percent of funds that buy small-cap value stocks. That category gained 10.6 percent, annualized, compared with a loss of 12.1 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc.
The fund returned 27.3 percent in the last 12 months, compared with a gain of 13.5 percent for its group and a 10.3 percent loss for the S.& P. 500.
Mr. Nasgovitz, 58, is the founder and president of Heartland Advisors, the fund's adviser. Mr. Miller, 49, is a senior vice president of the adviser. Heartland manages about $1.4 billion for institutions and individuals.
The managers buy stocks with market capitalizations of less than $1.5 billion. About two-thirds of the stocks in the portfolio are microcaps, defined as having market caps of less than $300 million. Over all, the portfolio companies' median market capitalization is $151 million.
Timing the purchase of a microcap stock is particularly tricky, Mr. Nasgovitz said. "Because the companies have little or no analyst coverage," he said, "they can be great stories but they may not get discovered until two years later."
To minimize these and other risks, the managers use traditional value measures, seeking companies with low ratios of price to earnings, price to book value and price to cash flow. 
They also want companies with relatively little debt, generally those with a ratio of debt to total capitalization of no more than 25 percent. That ratio now averages 20 percent for the portfolio, Mr. Miller said.
Mr. Nasgovitz says microcap stocks have also been performing well because they have received more attention from hedge funds, which he called a "growing and important side of the equity market."
The managers visit 500 to 1,000 companies a year, conducting what they call "on the ground" research.
"We like to get a feel for what's going on in the trenches from the people who are doing the production and making the sales," Mr. Miller said.
The managers start selling microcap stocks as they approach 85 to 90 percent of their price targets, and sell bigger companies as they reach their targets.
Among the fund's holdings are shares of the Regis Corporation, the hair salon company whose brands include Regis, MasterCuts and Trade Secret. The fund originally bought shares in January 2001 and has paid $14.90, on average, for the entire position. The shares now trade at $29.45; the managers say they believe shares will be worth $34 in the next 12 to 18 months.
Mr. Nasgovitz called Regis "a low-risk retail play" that has provided consistent and solid growth in same-store sales, those for salons open at least a year. 
Regis, which is based in Minneapolis, earned $1.59 a share in the 2002 fiscal year, compared with $1.26 a share the previous year.
The managers began buying shares of Ribapharm Inc., a biotechnology company in Costa Mesa, Calif., in April 2002 at $7.79, on average. The stock now trades at $5.58, compared with a target price of $10.
Ribapharm produces Ribaviran, which is used to treat hepatitis C. ICN Pharmaceuticals, which owns 80 percent of Ribapharm shares, spun off 20 percent of the company last year at $10 a share and is trying to repurchase those shares for $5.60. 
The fund, which has owned shares in ICN for years, acquired shares of Ribapharm in the spinoff..
Last week, a federal judge in California ruled that three generic versions of Ribavarin did not infringe on Ribapharm's patents. The company plans to appeal that ruling.
"Even if they lose that appeal, we believe Ribapharm should earn 40 cents a share next year, so it appears to us that the downside is already fully priced into the market," Mr. Nasgovitz said.
THE fund originally bought shares of the Presidential Life Corporation, an insurer based in Nyack, N.Y., in September 1994, paying $6.06, on average. The stock now trades at $15.59, compared with the managers' target price of $20.
The company recently wrote off some investments in high-yield telecommunications bonds, Mr. Nasgovitz said, but its tangible book value still exceeds $14 a share. He expects the company to earn $1.40 a share in 2004, up from the 90 cents a share projected for 2003. 
Company insiders have made more than 30 purchases so far this year, he added, and Herbert Kurz, the president and chairman, owns nearly 30 percent of the company.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Good for Your Conscience, if Not for Your Wallet

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of CBS MarketWatch. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
MUTUAL funds that call themselves socially responsible have had striking growth in assets over the last decade, fueled in part by the perception that they can more than hold their own with the rest of the fund industry. A new study, however, calls that idea into doubt.
 Such funds screen potential investments according to many social or ethical criteria. Common screens aim to avoid companies involved in the alcohol, tobacco, gambling or military industries, or companies that pollute the environment or mistreat workers. 
 The new study conflicts with many previous ones, which found that socially responsible funds, on average, outperformed other stock mutual funds in the 1990's. But many of those studies were conducted before the technology bubble burst in early 2000. The typical socially responsible fund has an outsized allocation to tech stocks, so its strong performance in the 90's might have reflected no more than that sector's strength.
Unless you believe that technology stocks will always beat the market, you shouldn't make long-term bets that socially responsible funds will outperform other funds.
Many socially responsible funds are partial to the technology sector because tech companies often score well on the funds' screens. In the five years through May, according to Shannon Zimmerman, fund analyst at Morningstar Inc., the average socially responsible equity fund allocated 23 percent of its portfolio to the tech and telecommunications sectors, versus an average of 14.5 percent for all other equity funds.
The heavy allocation to technology may also help to explain the socially responsible stock funds' recent relative strength. According to Lipper Inc., such funds produced an average gain of 15.5 percent in the second quarter, slightly better than the 15.4 percent total return for the S.& P. 500-stock index.
Three researchers at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania have found a way to analyze socially responsible funds that is less influenced by the performance of the tech sector. The study, by Christopher C. Geczy and Robert F. Stambaugh, both finance professors, and David Levin, one of their graduate students, can be found at http://finance.wharton.upenn.edu/stambaug/sri.pdf. 
The researchers analyzed socially responsible funds in light of market factors that historically have been most correlated with fund performance, like the average market capitalization of a fund's stock holdings or where its stocks fall on the value-growth spectrum. Within the universe of socially responsible funds, they found that there is a smaller range of meaningful choices among these factors. Over time, they say, that reduces returns for investors who build a portfolio of such funds.
Because socially responsible funds are more oriented toward growth stocks than value stocks, for example, investors may find that their portfolios will suffer over time. According to separate research by Eugene F. Fama of the University of Chicago and Kenneth R. French of Dartmouth, the average value stock outperformed the average growth stock by 3.5 percentage points a year, annualized, over the last 77 years.
OF course, you may not believe that this pattern will continue, but the Wharton researchers also tested other assumptions about market performance. In each case, they found that the smaller range of meaningful choices among socially responsible funds reduced investors' likely returns, often by several points a year.
Recently, some advocates of socially responsible investing have suggested that companies be avoided if they severely restrict shareholder rights. Screening companies this way might well bolster expected returns, because one academic study has found that, during the 1990's, companies with the fewest such restrictions outperformed those with the most. But because few socially responsible funds have added corporate governance criteria to their social screens, the Wharton study sheds no light on this strategy's profitability.
Even if you accept the study's conclusion that your returns will suffer if you invest in socially responsible mutual funds, you should not automatically avoid them. But investors in these funds need to be willing to bear an additional cost.

HEADLINE: It's a Fat World, After All 

BYLINE:  By ALISON LANGLEY

 BODY:
THE world economy may be slumping, but there is conspicuous growth in at least one area: waistlines.
 Been to Germany lately? Every third child under age 12 and every fifth teenager there is overweight. How about Greece, land of the much-ballyhooed Mediterranean diet? More than 70 percent of adult men and women in that nation are above their ideal size. The Middle East? About 60 percent of the women in Egypt are overweight. 
 Indeed, the problem of excess consumption has spread to every corner of the globe, except for pockets of Africa. The United States, in other words, no longer enjoys a competitive advantage when it comes to corpulence. 
Americans -- 61 percent of whom are overweight -- may take comfort in the fact that they're not the only ones packing on the pounds. But multinational food companies could soon find themselves carrying the increasing weight of the world upon their corporate shoulders. That's because the War Against Fat has become a global conflict, and the rules of engagement appear to be changing. While lawsuits seem to be the American tool of choice, European officials are far less averse than their counterparts in the United States to deploy their most powerful weapon: regulations.
For food companies, the stakes could be large. Last year, American companies exported 11.8 billion euros ($13.22 billion at current exchange rates) of agricultural products to the European Union, everything from cranberries and candy bars to cereals and sodas. It's not at all certain that corporations can satisfy shareholder hunger for growth and still fulfill demands by regulators to sell smaller portions and healthier foods. 
The message to consume less is hardly a capitalist notion. Food companies grow by selling to more people, or convincing existing customers to eat more. "They don't have a lot of potential for expansion left in the United States," said Marion Nestle, chairwoman of the nutrition and food studies department at New York University and author of "Food Politics: How the Food Industry Influences Nutrition and Health" (University of California Press, 2002). Because of that, she said, American companies have been exporting the salty, sugary foods they are known for and undermining the generally healthier eating habits of other countries. 
Unlike the United States, Europe has a tradition of regulating problems away. Chances are small that the Bush administration will threaten food companies with more regulations. In fact, the Food and Drug Administration recently made it easier for companies to make health and nutrition claims on food. The European Union, on the other hand, proposed a directive last week that would make it much tougher for companies to make such claims. 
DAVID BYRNE, the health commissioner for the European Union, seemed to catch the food industry by surprise on Wednesday when he proposed the regulations, which would prevent companies from marketing a food as having a health or nutrition benefit if it was also high in salt, sugar or fat. Mr. Byrne has not yet completed the profile of what foods would be affected, so executives say it is too early to panic. The rules, if passed by the European Parliament, would go into effect in 2005. 
Still, if Mr. Byrne has his way, the makers of most processed foods, from snacks to soups, may be barred from saying the products are nutritious.
Later this year, Mr. Byrne plans to propose changes in the way nutrition labels are written, to make them more comprehensible to consumers and to allow only products that are low in salt, sugar and fat to be fortified with vitamins and minerals. Food that did not meet certain criteria could not be marketed with claims that they are nutritious. 
In March, the World Health Organization issued a report that connected improper diet, along with a decline in physical activity, to a devastating rise in chronic diseases like heart conditions, diabetes, osteoporosis and cancer. By 2020, chronic diseases will account for nearly three-fourths of all deaths worldwide, the report said. This fall, the W.H.O. will release a draft of recommendations to its 191 member states on how to address the problem, and it is expected to consider important issues for business, like nutritional labeling and marketing to children. 
A result is that food companies, long believed to be recession-proof, are facing scrutiny by investors who are factoring in the risk of litigation and regulation in valuing them, according to a recent research report by the UBS Investment Bank. 
"There is a slow, but clear, evolution of how regulators are looking at these issues," said Arnaud Langlois, vice president for equity research at J. P. Morgan Chase in London. The impact on food companies, he said, is not all negative. 
"It doesn't change our view of the sector," Mr. Langlois said. "To meet consumer demand for healthier products, companies will have to reposition and upgrade their product portfolio. We believe that consumers are prepared to pay a premium for health coupled with taste." 
Companies may need to lower the salt, sugar and fats in their foods and yet maintain appealing tastes and textures. "Ultimately, they will change if they are forced to, either by regulation or consumer pressure," said Jason Streets, an analyst at the UBS Investment Bank in London. 
How companies react will depend in part on how well positioned they are in the market to offer healthier choices. Companies with the most to lose are those that mainly sell foods or drinks that are high in fat, sugar or salt -- like Cadbury Schweppes of Britain and Hershey Foods and McDonald's of the United States -- according to a report by J. P. Morgan Chase. The report argued that companies that are more diverse in their food lines, like Nestle of Switzerland, would find it easier to adjust. Companies that cannot spend the money to develop healthier products should consider acquiring them, the report said. 
Even foods that are considered healthy, like cereals, could be negatively affected by the European regulations. Under the proposed European Union directive, products cannot be labeled as healthy, even if they contain fortified vitamins and minerals, if the products have a high amount of sugar.
If put into effect, that change would have an impact on a company like Kellogg, based in Battle Creek, Mich. Some of its cereals would meet the proposed guidelines; others, especially those popular with children, would not. Aileen Thompson, European director of Kellogg Management Services in London, said the company would not comment on the impact of the proposed rules. 
Others companies, like Nestle; Kraft Foods of Northfield, Ill.; Unilever, the British-Dutch conglomerate; and Groupe Danone of France, are already repositioning themselves and their research and development departments to offer foods that contain healthier oils and use less salt and sugar.
But it takes time to develop the new products, and companies cannot afford to satisfy regulators but fail consumers. "That's death," said Francois-Xavier Perroud, vice president for communications at Nestle.
At an investment seminar in May, Nestle's chief executive, Peter Brabeck-Letmathe, underscored the company's commitment to offering healthier foods, saying it was focusing its research in the nutritious foods he considers the growth markets. 
Sometimes, development takes years. Nestle has a line of fermented milk products called LC1 (a name derived from an active ingredient) that took 30 years to create. In 1964, Nestle microbiologists identified a bacterium, known as La1, that colonizes the digestive system and stimulates immune response. 
By 1990, Nestle had built up a strong dossier for a novel product with a proven health benefit. In 1994, it rolled out its first LC1 products in France with the claim that they reinforced natural defenses. They are now available throughout Europe, Australia and Brazil. Under the proposed European Union guidelines, LC1 would be allowed to claim a health benefit.
At the same seminar, Mr. Brabeck-Letmathe acknowledged that the nutrient profile of a diet is only one factor in a consumer's food choices. And he assured investors that Nestle had not forgotten that people also eat food for pleasure. 
THE pressure for regulation, in light of the medical costs of obesity, had raised questions about whether Nestle would stick to its confectionery business, he said. "Let me assure you," he said, "this will not change Nestle's commitment to the confectionery business."
Some companies are already reacting to the threat of lawsuits and more regulations. In early July, Kraft said it would stop promoting its products in schools and make smaller portions. It made the announcement after it was the target of a lawsuit in May by a San Francisco lawyer who wanted to block Kraft from selling Oreos to children because the cookies contain trans fats, which exist in hydrogenated oil. He soon dropped the suit, reportedly because he felt that the publicity from the action had raised awareness about trans fats.
Last September, McDonald's, based in Oak Brook, Ill., announced that it would seek a healthier alternative to the oil with trans fats that it uses to cook French fries.
Mr. Brabeck-Letmathe pledged in May that Nestle would stop marketing jumbo candy bars to children and would be clearer in its labeling. In Britain, it is removing hydrogenated vegetable fat from some confectionery. That, in turn, prompted Cadbury Schweppes to announce a review of its use of hydrogenated fats in confectionery and and other products.
Executives say they believe measures to fight obesity should be voluntary, and they point to these initiatives as proof that the industry can police itself.
But some are skeptical that companies will make real changes. Prof. Nestle from New York University noted that McDonald's said last year that it would change the kind of oil it uses, but that it still has not done so. McDonald's has said that it is carrying out tests to develop the approach that will work best. 
Amalia Waxman, project director of the World Health Organization's food initiative, said experience had shown that self-regulation was less effective than what she calls co-regulation, in which all stakeholders, including corporations, consumer groups and governments, work together to ensure that minimum standards are met.
Still, many executives at food companies reject the notion that they are the bad guys who are somehow to blame for the obesity epidemic. They say individuals have to take responsibility for what they eat and how much they exercise. 
Luis Cantarell, deputy executive vice president for Nestle's nutrition division, says there are no good foods and bad foods. "The way you use the food, the way you use the information," he said, "is another thing."
