HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: SECURITY; 
U.S. Is Creating An Iraqi Militia To Relieve G.I.'s

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 20 

 BODY:
The United States is creating a new Iraqi civil defense force within the next 45 days that is intended to free up thousands of American troops for antiguerrilla missions and to put an Iraqi face on the occupation's postwar security efforts, two top American generals said today.
 The immediate goal is to field about 7,000 American-trained militiamen to protect supply convoys and replace American troops now guarding power plants and ammunition depots. 
 The new Iraqi Governing Council has strongly supported creating an Iraqi militia, which appears to go well beyond a proposal under consideration at the Pentagon to hire private contractors to provide security at sites around the country.
"Over time, it'll free up an awful lot of American forces," said Gen. John P. Abizaid, who is making his first visit to Iraq as the new head of the United States Central Command. 
The persistent violence, two months after President Bush declared an end to major combat, was underscored today when two soldiers were killed and one was wounded in an ambush near Mosul in the north. Also today, an Iraqi driver for a United Nations agency died when his convoy was attacked near Baghdad.
In the southern city of Najaf, United States marines found themselves in a standoff with more than 10,000 mainly Shiite demonstrators, angered by rumors that American troops had harassed a cleric who had condemned the United States-led occupation. Page A6. 
Armed resistance to the American-led occupation is coming from a small number of "professional killers" drawn from "remnants of the old regime regrouping in squad-level attacks," said the United States administrator for Iraq, L. Paul Bremer III, on "Fox News Sunday."
The attacks pose "no strategic threat to us," Mr. Bremer said, in a guardedly upbeat assessment of conditions in Iraq. He cited as signs of progress the restoration of basic services, economic reforms and the recent establishment of the Governing Council, and he said it was "quite possible" that a constitutional conference, probably to open in September, could write a constitution that would lead to elections and a new government within a year.
Eventually, General Abizaid said, the Iraqi militia may also join American soldiers in joint raids against guerrilla fighters, who he said were waging increasingly sophisticated attacks against American troops.
The plan to establish an Iraqi civil defense force, first reported in The Washington Post, reflects the Pentagon's urgent priority to quell the mounting attacks against American troops and to use an interim Iraqi force to help do that until a larger Iraqi national army is formed in the coming months and years.
Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz, who is nearing the end of a five-day mission in Iraq, has heard repeatedly from tribal and civic leaders that the occupation authority must give Iraqis a greater role in governing and securing their country in order for the American-led effort to have credibility with the Iraqi public.
Today, Mr. Wolfowitz said that recruiting Iraqis for security and intelligence tasks was essential for the rebuilding of Iraq to succeed. Small numbers of Iraqis and Iraqi-Americans have already served as interpreters and scouts for American commandos and regular forces. "We need more of these people," Mr. Wolfowitz said. 
Establishing the militia as an interim Iraqi force is an acknowledgment that training and mobilizing an Iraqi national army will take years to accomplish. Bush administration officials in Washington and American commanders here say they cannot afford to wait that long.
Under the American plan, eight battalions with about 850 Iraqi militiamen each will train under and then work with army divisions in various regions around the country, said Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, the commander of allied forces in Iraq. After 45 days, the second group of eight battalions, or nearly 7,000 more militiamen, could be recruited and trained, General Sanchez said.
The makeup of each unit would mirror the demographics of that particular region and would probably include both men and women. Previous military service would not be required but any officer who served in the Iraqi Army above the rank of lieutenant colonel would be barred. Local leaders would help identify militia recruits, who would receive basic training in human rights, weapons handling and patrol techniques.
"Probably the most important contribution they will bring will be putting an Iraqi face on the security problems of the country and ensuring that wherever our soldiers are, Iraqis are contributing to that security," General Sanchez said.
Many details still need to be worked out. General Sanchez and his boss, General Abizaid, focused on different aspects of the program.
General Sanchez said the forces would focus on basic duties like convoy protection, at least initially. "These are not forces intended to conduct offensive operations," General Sanchez told reporters during a lunch interview. "They will be on patrol with us. They will be on fixed sites."
Cautioning that he was not necessarily contradicting his subordinate, General Abizaid said the militia could eventually take on more challenging offensive missions but he did not say when that might happen.
"Over time, as confidence increases in working with these guys, we will ask them to do more and more complicated things," General Abizaid said at the lunch. "And it's important we do."
Some allied commanders have on their own already starting training Iraqi civil defense forces. The Army's 101st Airborne Division has trained one company of Iraqi militiamen in Mosul to guard an ammunition depot and is preparing to graduate three more companies. British forces in Basra, in the south, have organized a new Iraqi patrol force. General Abizaid said the American military needed to change its cultural mindset when it came to dealing with indigenous forces, adding that the United States needed to "train them and have them be prepared to conduct a full range of operations with us."
Recruiting for Iraq's new national army started recently, but American officials have said it will take a year to form an initial force of 12,000 soldiers and three years to create a 40,000-soldier force. The new militia could eventually be folded into the army, officials said.
"The important thing about the new Iraqi army is not the number of divisions or the type of equipment they have, but whether or not the officer corps respects the people they protect and serve the government," General Abizaid said.
Even as Mr. Wolfowitz has fielded Iraqi complaints for more security, he has telephoned his boss in Washington, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, at least twice in two days to try to agree on a workable militia plan, aides said.
The Pentagon is hoping that new Iraqi security forces and some 30,000 allied forces that will be arriving this summer will allow the United States to begin sending home many of the nearly 150,000 forces it has here now.
General Abizaid said the size and makeup of the American forces was likely to remain the same for the next few months, but he said he was planning to replace heavy armored forces that were needed in the war with lighter, more mobile troops that could patrol more efficiently in cities and respond quickly to fresh tips on the location of guerrilla fighters.
"A lot of people say if you just throw more troops at it, you're going to solve the problems," General Abizaid said. "But it's not a matter of boots per square meter. It's a matter of focused intelligence, and then troops that are agile enough to carry out missions in a manner that can cause surprise and take down the targets precisely."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Relearning The Wonders Of the City

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK

 BODY:
OLD friends who moved recently to New York are reacquainting themselves with the city and talked about it the other night over dinner.
 They are lawyers and writers, and work kept them in Washington for many years, but life changed and they came home. Both had lived before in New York; he in fact is a Brooklyn native who, now 70-plus, had visited often. But you would think they were tourists seeing the city for the first time. They were downright giddy. 
 We share their giddiness because it was fun.
Consider their new block. In New York, a block can be a neighborhood. Theirs, not far from Gramercy Park, happens to include a strip joint. An upscale strip joint, if there is such a thing. But a strip joint it is.
In other words, a couple returning to New York after a long absence buys a luxury co-op and finds a strip club across the street. Mistake? Apartment-hunting again?
No way. They love it. Safest block in the city, they report. And the quietest. No loitering. "Everybody's a little ashamed, you know," the husband explained. He pulled his jacket over his head to mimic the street theater.
The strip joint is guarded by a large, bulky fellow called "Street," who, in famously anonymous New York, watches out for everyone on the block.
Street quickly got to know the newcomers. In fact, he knows them by their first names, admonished their college-age daughter for coming home late after a party, even chatted with her father about the political job he had years ago in Washington.
How Street knew all this is not clear. Maybe he recognized him? Or someone pointed him out? No matter, it's fine with the new (and former) New Yorker. "This guy's the essence of New York," he said of Street. "Wouldn't find him in Washington," which is surely true and surely just fine with Washington.
Let's admit it, the capital is easier and so much less frazzling than New York. Its subway stations look like museums, and the trains are clean. But they do not go very far. Ours do, to the delight of the prodigal couple. They take subways everywhere, from Harlem, where he has some business, to Midtown, where she works.
Which leads us to the matter of baby carriages. Baby carriages? "People lugging babies in carriages up and down the subway steps," the former Washington lawyer explained. "They just do it."
They have to, mainly in older, unrenovated stations without elevators (or with broken ones). Our friend said he realizes that but is still impressed with the coping mechanism of New Yorkers. "I saw some people struggling on the stairs with a stroller one day. I told them: 'You're heroes. You're all heroes.' " He drew curious stares, of course.
His wife is happy to be reminded of the breadth of New York. For instance, a quite-pregnant young woman she knows is getting married and asked for help finding a wedding dress of a certain configuration. Research on the Internet turned up the perfect shop. "It's right here in New York," said our friend. "Check it out."
We did. There is indeed a store, called Mom's Night Out, that specializes in maternity evening clothes, including wedding dresses. It is not the only one of its kind, but it's right on the Upper East Side and near the top of the list on Google. And near a subway.
THESE are the things New Yorkers take for granted, and since it's a tough, tough town, we have that right. Tragedy is never far away in New York. A subway fire. A dead child found wrapped in a plastic bag in the trash.
Frustration is always with us, too. Tax increases and the economy, the continuing impact of Sept. 11, the homeless, the unemployed, the loser judges. Unrelenting.
But there are not many places that can boast of a benign bouncer and a transportation system that attracts prominent lawyers and stroller-bearing parents -- people from different worlds.
It is, the Washington transplants recognized, the contrasts and the options that make New York New York. Not everyone needs a wedding dress designed for pregnancy. Nice to know the store that carries it is nearby, though.
Free Shakespeare in the Park is back, and sparkling Central Park is celebrating its 150th birthday. New Yorkers can join in. Or pay no attention, but know that it's here.
"Isn't it amazing that this city works?" Ann Richards, the former governor of Texas now living in New York, said to some friends this weekend. It really is. We forget. Nice to be reminded.

HEADLINE: Report Cites Factors Impeding Black Gains 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Black families' gains in income and education are being undermined by rising incarceration rates and a persistent unemployment gap compared with whites, the Urban League said in its latest report on the state of black America.
 Black families are "strong but challenged," said Marc Morial, president of the Urban League. 
 The annual report, scheduled for release on Wednesday, is a collection of nine essays written by experts on race, social justice, health, psychology and civil rights. 
Robert Hill, a senior researcher at the Rockville, Md., firm Westat, examines how the social and economic status of black families has changed.
Racism remains, he wrote. In the last 30 years, "there has been a strong shift from Jim Crow -- the overt manifestation of racial hatred by individuals and white society -- to James Crow, Esquire -- the maintenance of racial inequality through covert processes of structure and institutions," he wrote.
Though blacks are no more likely than whites to mistreat their children, they are overrepresented in the foster care system, Mr. Hill wrote. 
Teenage pregnancy contributes to the instability of black families; black teenagers are about three times more likely than whites to have babies out of wedlock, Mr. Hill said. Other factors that have hurt black families, he said, include drug use and AIDS.
Economically, a decline in manufacturing and the rise of service industries meant many black workers went from higher-paying blue-collar jobs to much lower-paying white-collar service jobs, he said.

HEADLINE: Bush Loyalists Compete for Spots on President's A-Team by Raising Record Money for 2004 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20 

 BODY:
As President Bush's re-election campaign races to accumulate the largest treasury in history, a similarly fierce contest has begun among his best-connected supporters. Raising $100,000 for the president is a bit passe in this competition; now loyalists must bring in $200,000 or more to be considered top-tier, and they had better come with sharp elbows and plenty of prosperous friends.
 "Everyone in town is trying to be a Pioneer or Ranger," said Jack Abramoff, a top Republican lobbyist here, using the campaign's terms for the most elite levels of money collectors. "But the only way to do it is to have contacts outside of D.C., which fortunately I do. So far I've raised about $120,000, and I haven't even really started making calls." 
 Competition, a bedrock principle of President Bush's economic philosophy, has proved enormously successful in building his record-setting campaign treasury. Of the $34.4 million raised through June by the Bush-Cheney campaign, a quarter has come in through just 68 fund-raisers who are jockeying with each other to bring in the most checks. Those fund-raisers, and scores of others who have signed pledge cards to join them, will become increasingly important as the campaign pushes toward its goal of banking at least $170 million and probably closer to $200 million. 
Industry moguls, lawyers and even governors are vying for the right to become Pioneers (those who have raised $100,000) or top-level Rangers ($200,000), the designation that shares the name of the baseball team once partly owned by Mr. Bush. When a fund-raiser gets a friend or business contact to write a check, the collector asks the donor to put the fund-raiser's tracking number in the corner, so the campaign will know who solicited the contribution.
Those who do so catch the eye of the White House, having demonstrated their loyalty to the administration in a way far more prominent than simply writing a check for the legal maximum of $2,000 per person.
"I had really wanted to be the first Ranger, but I didn't make it," said Carole L. Bionda, a Pioneer and the chairwoman-elect of Associated Builders and Contractors Inc., a large trade association. "But I still have a good shot at making it. It's fun, it's good for our organization, and it allows our members to express their support for the president."
Many of those on the list of top fund-raisers, released by the Bush campaign last week, were also Pioneers in the 2000 campaign, when that was the highest level attainable and the maximum contribution was $1,000. Some are newcomers to the campaign, while others are among the president's oldest friends and financial backers.
Almost all are successful business leaders: developers, lawyers or manufacturers who say they strongly agree with the president's economic and security policies. Four of those on the list own major-league sports franchises. Two are elected officials: Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Representative Thomas M. Reynolds of New York, the chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. Others previously held office, including former Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida and Alfonse M. D'Amato, the former senator from New York.
Most of the fund-raisers said in interviews last week that they wanted to help ensure Mr. Bush's re-election and had no ulterior motive for collecting money for the president, although several said they were looking forward to the party for Rangers and Pioneers that the campaign has scheduled in Texas next month. A few, however, acknowledged that there were other benefits to being a "bundler," as the fund-raisers are known.
Ms. Bionda, for example, said her trade group has several issues, including changes to the laws regarding private health plans, to take to Washington, and said that her fund-raising could be useful. Mr. Reynolds said the president's re-election could also help Mr. Reynolds in his job of electing more Republicans to the House. Many other bundlers lead businesses whose fortunes can depend on the administration's tax or regulatory decisions.
The prominence and access that bundling can provide have long worried critics of big-money politics. Fred Wertheimer, president of Democracy 21, a Washington group that advocates campaign finance reform, said the reliance on big fund-raisers can subvert the principle of contribution limits.
"When you have a formalized system like Pioneers and Rangers, the $200,000 fund-raiser becomes the equivalent of the $200,000 donor, and that's dangerous to the political system," Mr. Wertheimer said. "Chasing a huge amount of money, as the Bush campaign is doing, just increases the stake for fund-raisers who can bring in huge sums, and increases their clout and influence."
He advocates requiring all candidates to reveal their major fund-raisers, which they currently do not have to do. The Bush campaign voluntarily released its list of bundlers, which some Democratic candidates have not done.
"The president believes in as much transparency and disclosure as possible," said Nicolle Devenish, the Bush campaign's spokeswoman. "Those are his principles and values."
She said that bundlers had no option of remaining unlisted, and she rejected the idea that they had any enhanced clout with the administration. More than 80 percent of the 105,000 individual donations received so far, she said, were for $200 or less. Records filed with the Federal Election Commission show that about 85 percent of the money the campaign has collected so far came in donations of $1,000 or more.
It is not possible from public records to directly link fund-raisers to contributors, but some patterns are not hard to deduce, particularly when corporate executives solicit their employees or colleagues for donations. The Center for Responsive Politics compiled a list of the companies and firms whose employees gave the most to the Bush campaign. At six businesses the employees collectively gave more than $100,000, and each of the six had a top executive on the bundler list.
The six businesses included four financial companies -- Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers, Bear Stearns, and Credit Suisse First Boston -- and two law firms, Blank Rome in Philadelphia and Haynes & Boone in Dallas.
Many on the bundler list raised their money by sponsoring dinners or other events and taking credit for those who came and contributed, while others worked the telephones. Lawrence Bathgate II, a lawyer from Lakewood, N.J., who has ties to the Bush family, said he sent hundreds of handwritten letters to a network of friends and associates. Mr. Pataki sponsored a fund-raising dinner in New York in June and also made telephone calls, said his spokeswoman, Lisa Dewald Stoll.
Many of those contacted said it was much easier to raise money this year than in 2000 because Mr. Bush is now an incumbent broadly popular among Republicans and because the new campaign finance law doubled the individual contribution limit to $2,000. Bob Tuttle, a Beverly Hills car dealer whose father, Holmes Tuttle, was one of Ronald Reagan's earliest supporters, said most of the people he called gave the maximum amount. He said there have also been contributions from unexpected sources.
"I called one fellow I know, and his secretary said, 'Would you mind if I sent you a donation, too?' " said Mr. Tuttle, director of presidential personnel in the Reagan White House.
"I said, 'Mind? Of course not, send it in.' And she sent $25."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: IRAQI UNREST; 
In Shiite Holy City of Najaf, A Sudden Anti-U.S. Storm

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: NAJAF, Iraq, July 20 

 BODY:
The cleric and the lieutenant colonel stood just inches apart under the broiling noon sun today, white turban to camouflage helmet, trading invective about the deployment of American troops in this holy city.
 Behind the American officer, a line of about two dozen marines stood vigilant, their bayonets newly fixed to their rifles. Behind the cleric, a sweep of thousands of demonstrators, most of them trucked in from Baghdad, chanting slogans like "No Americans after today" and "No to America, no to colonialism, no to tyranny, no to the Devil!" 
 So lies the suddenly uneasy state of relations between the United States forces and the younger, more militant clergymen of Iraq's majority Shiite community. 
Until now, interactions between the Americans and the Iraqis in Najaf have been calm, free of the random violence rampant in the country's Sunni heartland. 
But a sudden storm erupted on Saturday after Moktada al-Sadr, the scion of a clan of beloved clerics and the most vocal supporter of Iranian-style theocracy in Iraq, asserted that American forces were encircling his home. They were bent on arresting him, his aides announced, after an incendiary sermon on Friday in which he rejected the American-appointed Governing Council and called for the formation of an Islamic army. 
It was, said Lt. Col. Christopher C. Conlin, the commanding officer here, a deliberate misunderstanding. 
There had indeed been Apache helicopters clattering overhead and extra troops on the streets, but that was to provide security for a visit by Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz, Colonel Conlin said.
The temporary ramping up of the United States presence could not be explained in advance for security reasons, and afterward the American officer relied on members of Najaf's City Council to pass the word. He wished the demonstrators would take their complaints to the new City Council. 
The abrupt storm this weekend underscored a point made by a review of the Iraq reconstruction effort released last week by a panel from the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. The lack of Iraqis involved in the reconstruction at all levels, widespread unemployment and woefully inadequate means of communicating what is happening to the country's 24 million people have combined to fuel an ever-higher level of frustration and anger about the American presence. 
Men like Mr. Sadr and his followers, determined to harness that frustration to wrest a greater say in Iraq's future, are stepping into the void. 
"They used to think that they could marginalize the Shiites, that we would accept anything," said Sheik Khalid al-Khatami, an aide to Mr. Sadr, standing on a balcony beneath the gold dome of the tomb of Imam Ali, the founder of the Shiite sect, as the clerics whipped up the crowd. "That is a false impression. Neither the Americans nor any of the foreigners know how strong we are."
Najaf is the home to four respected ayatollahs, the senior Shiite leaders to whom the faithful look for guidance on virtually all aspects of daily life. The ayatollahs and their supporters were conspicuously absent from today's events, because they view Mr. Sadr and his followers as little more than young hotheads determined to make a name for themselves by stirring up violence against the occupation.
Mr. Sadr's father, Ayatollah Muhammad Sadiq al-Sadr, was an outspoken defender of the Shiites before being gunned down in 1999 in a killing attributed to Saddam Hussein's henchman.
Out of respect for his father and not wanting to increase the younger cleric's allure, the ayatollahs and other Shiite political groups have mostly remained silent in public about the situation. 
"Moktada Sadr and his supporters are trying to drag us into this kind of confrontation, this kind of division between Shiites on the street," said a spokesman for the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, the most established Shiite group and a participant in the Governing Council.
But even the local Supreme Council office had apparently not gotten word that the American military movements on Saturday were not reacting to Mr. Sadr's Friday sermon. "The American policy should be calmer; they should not react so hastily to what he said," the spokesman added. 
He and others say that much of the new militancy in the Shiite community is being pushed by former Baathists, happy to find any channel they can to create unrest. 
Support for the demonstrators came from Iran, too. The protest opened with a message of support from Ayatollah Kathim al-Husseini al-Haeri, an Iraqi clergyman in the holy Iranian city of Qum. Members of the Governing Council were all American agents, he said in a message read aloud to the crowd, and the clerics were the legitimate rulers. 
Random comments on the street appeared to show little support for the demonstration on Saturday among the people in Najaf itself, and even two clergyman wandering through the shrine were wondering what all the fuss was about. 
"What do we need an Islamic army for?" said Riad Abu al-Awady, a 23-year-old Najaf resident. "Many members of my family fought in Saddam's wars and they are all dead. What Iraqis need is water, electricity, security, and we want to work."
Outside the headquarters of the United States forces here, on the old university campus, a young clergyman named Aws al-Khafaji, a member of Mr. Sadr's circle, made fiery speeches against the American military. He said the Americans were ruling through a "sissy" council, despoiling the holy city of Najaf with their presence, and spreading Western corruption. 
Then he and a few others walked forward a few times to confront Colonel Conlin, at one point handing over a list of demands -- including one that American forces leave the city immediately. 
"He is frustrated because this city is peaceful and he has a low support base here," the officer said about Mr. Sadr. "This is the city of ayatollahs, and this is just a young, inexperienced guy." 
But the young guy had deployed thousands of angry demonstrators on the Americans' doorstep. Colonel Conlin brought up a loudspeaker system of his own, addressing the crowd through an interpreter. His soldiers did not try to surround Mr. Sadr's house, he said, and they had no interest in arresting him. 
The colonel said the unruly demonstrators were blaspheming in the city of Abraham, and he warned that they must disband or be considered a threat to the American forces. 
Much of what the officer said was lost in the chanting of the crowd, and some of the translation was poor -- the Arabic version suggested that the crowd must show respect or be considered a threat.
But the clergymen, after reluctantly agreeing that both sides would air their viewpoint before the city's most prominent ayatollah, took their supporters home. There would, they said, be another demonstration on Monday.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Bush Takes a Brief Break From Relaxing to Rake In $7 Million

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: CRAWFORD, Tex., July 20 

 BODY:
President Bush never seems happier or more relaxed than when he is back here at his ranch. But this weekend, unwinding proved particularly profitable: He raised $7 million from Texas Republicans with minimal effort and was whisked back to his own living room by sunset -- exactly how the rest of his summer is shaping up.
 Mr. Bush spoke at two fund-raisers, one on Friday night in Dallas and another on Saturday evening in Houston, delivering a version of his new campaign speech at each stop. The speech is about 2,700 words long. So, if this weekend was representative, his campaign coffers swell by about $1,300 a word -- not bad for a weekend, especially one primarily devoted to tending to the ranch. 
 The new speech starts with an elephant joke: Mr. Bush says that, at a nature reserve in Botswana during his recent Africa trip, "I learned a lot about our party's mascot."
In Houston, he next told the crowd of about 700 that "you're laying the groundwork for what is going to be a great national victory in November of 2004." Then he praises his staff and refers to Vice President Dick Cheney, no slouch at fund-raising either in recent weeks, to set up his other laugh-line of the night.
"Our country has had no finer vice president than Dick Cheney," Mr. Bush said at both fund-raisers, and then, after waiting for the applause to die down, he added: "Mother may have a different thought." It is a reference, of course, to President Bush's father, who served as a far less influential vice president to Ronald Reagan than Mr. Cheney is to the current president.
But what is most interesting about Mr. Bush's new speech is the way that he puts the two brief wars of his presidency -- first in Afghanistan, then in Iraq -- to political use. Mr. Bush makes no references to the troubles American forces have encountered in each country. Instead, he portrays himself as a liberator.
"Fifty million people in those two countries once lived under tyranny," Mr. Bush said in Houston. "Today, they live in freedom."
He has a riff on the economy as well, one that describes himself as inheriting a mess, facing a war, combating corruption and taking decisive action. It is hardly the spin that Mr. Bush's political opponents might put on the same era.
"Two and a half years ago, we inherited an economy in recession," Mr. Bush said in Houston. "And then the attacks on our country, and scandals in corporate America, and war affected the people's confidence," he added, speaking in shorthand about the major headlines of the past 2 1/2 years. "But we acted. We passed tough new laws to hold corporate criminals to account. And to get the economy going again, we have twice led the United States Congress to pass historic tax relief for the American people."
There is no mention, not surprisingly, of the record deficits or the rising unemployment rate -- though clearly those issues are at the forefront of his political team's concerns as Mr. Bush prepares to travel this week to Philadelphia and Michigan to make the case for his economic policy. (It is a trip he will combine with more fund-raising.) 
Mr. Bush is expected to return here next weekend and stay until Labor Day, though leaving for more trips to press his economic agenda and raise money.
Mr. Bush did not dally in Houston on Saturday evening -- he flew straight back to the ranch. Around noon today, he led selected victims on his staff in a three-mile run in the 100-degree heat, with a medical team keeping pace. He then showed up late this afternoon to greet Italy's embattled prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, as he landed on the president's helicopter pad for an overnight visit.
Mr. Berlusconi was one of the few European supporters of the war in Iraq, and his visit here underscored the fact that France's president, Jacques Chirac, and Germany' chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, who opposed American efforts to build a broader coalition, are not likely to find themselves dining under the stars in Crawford anytime soon.
Mr. Bush could not resist tweaking the members of the news media as they stood in the blazing sun awaiting a glimpse of a Crawford tradition: the president, driving his white pickup truck with Texas plates, arriving to pick up his guests.
As he passed a collection of sweating American and Italian reporters, Mr. Bush, showing his compassionate conservative side, rolled down his window, waved, and said: "Let me turn down my air conditioner -- how y'all doing out there?"

HEADLINE: Race and Politics, a Familiar Pair, Seem to Be Back in Town 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
After years of ugly confrontations between City Hall and various minorities throughout the city, capped by a racially divisive 2001 mayoral primary, racial tensions in New York City seemed to have quieted over the last 18 months. A new mayor committed to soothing the racial storms and a City Council chock-full of new members, a large percentage of them blacks and Hispanics, have combined in part to make it so. 
 But a number of recent episodes suggest that race has re-entered the political conversation in New York, at least in discussions of sharing power. 
 Last week, members of the City Council accused Speaker Gifford Miller of supporting environmental racism by delaying action on a bill that would have tougher requirements for the removal of lead paint in city apartments. In that same week, members of the Democratic Party and others argued that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's attempt to remove party labels from municipal elections would hurt minority candidates. 
Two months ago, the teachers' union sued Chancellor Joel I. Klein, accusing him of racial discrimination because the Bloomberg administration's plan to lay off nearly 800 classroom aides disproportionately affected blacks and Hispanics. 
Further, Mr. Bloomberg's poll numbers among racial minorities are as low as some of the worst faced by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, in spite of the Bloomberg administration's efforts to reach out to minority communities.
Why this is happening is a matter of much debate among Democrats and Republicans alike, and a matter of concern on both the legislative and executives sides of City Hall. At the very least, said political experts and aides to elected officials, the city could be on the verge of another racially charged set of municipal elections, potentially unlike any the city has seen since David N. Dinkins was mayor.
"Race has been and will continue to be a very big issue in New York politics in a way that is probably not for the better of our civic life," said Howard Wolfson, a Democratic consultant who was executive director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2002.
While most political experts agree that racial disputes during political campaigns tend to harm minority candidates most, the question of race does not simply coalesce around tensions between whites and minorities, as it did in the 2001 primary. In that battle, Mark Green was criticized for an advertisement that questioned the competence of his opponent, Fernando Ferrer, who is Hispanic. 
Already, there is whispering in Democratic circles about which potential candidate, Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., who is black, or Mr. Ferrer has the best shot at forming a coalition of minority voters.
In an interview, Mr. Ferrer, who has yet to say whether he will run for office, said he believed his party had learned from the racial flare-up of the last campaign. "I think it is axiomatic in a diverse constituency" to keep racial disputes from arising in an election, he said. 
"You want to try and bring people together as much as you can," he said. "That is a lesson that has been learned by the Republican Party. That was what Bloomberg and Pataki learning Spanish was about," said Mr. Ferrer. He was present at the news conference in which Mr. Miller's delay on the lead paint bill was denounced by Councilwoman Helen D. Foster as environmental racism, though he later denounced the rhetoric. 
Numerous people involved in New York City politics for years argue that race never loses its currency in this city, but awaits a policy issue or a political campaign to bring it out in the open. 
"Race always ripples right under the skin of the body politic," said Norman Adler, a political consultant. "If it finds an opening, it pops up. And sometimes it is a convenient rhetorical tool." For instance, on the issue of lead paint, "the people who are for a tougher law tried other internal means in the Council," Mr. Adler said, "and couldn't move it. So race seemed a way to organize around the issue."
Once the race card is played, it is difficult to put it back in the deck. Mr. Bloomberg is still seething, his aides say, over the lawsuit filed by Randi Weingarten, head of the teachers' union, charging racism in the plan to lay off paraprofessionals from the Department of Education. Ms. Weingarten says now that while she thought the suit had merits, she regrets her role in characterizing the mayor's intentions. 
"I think I should have made it very clear when we filed it that this was not a case where I was questioning the mayor's intent or Joel Klein's intent," Ms. Weingarten said, "and that the lawsuit questioned the effect of the choice. The effect of laying off all these paraprofessionals was that it hurt minorities more than nonminorities. But I should have been much clearer that I was talking about disparate impact instead of intentionality." 
In many ways, while racial tensions have certainly not gone away in the last two years, they have seemed dormant. Many political experts, elected officials and others credit Mayor Bloomberg in part for this. 
They point to the mayor's efforts to reach out to minority politicians who were not welcome in City Hall for many years, and note that he has visited roughly 20 black churches since he was elected, a large number for a mayor whose political ventures outside Manhattan have been limited until recently. Many credit him with moving swiftly to discipline police officials connected to the death of a black civil servant during a police raid. 
It is also true -- and this is not good news for Mr. Bloomberg -- that race has been replaced or at least enveloped by class as the central tenet of voter discontent in the city. And that class-centered discontent is expressed by racial minorities, who tend to dominate low-income groups, and by those white voters who have lost their jobs, watched their taxes rise and suffered higher fees, all while Mr. Bloomberg has been in office. 
While there have been no significant protests around a racial issue since he took office, there have been plenty related to the budget, and the signs have been carried by people of all races.
"The 2005 race will be about the economy," said Roberto Ramirez, a Bronx Democratic leader. "The hike in property taxes, the sense in the city that there is not enough affordable housing, and the feeling that the city needs a mayor who recognizes what the average New Yorker faces every day."
In that sense, several political experts said, any Democrat who wants a clear shot at City Hall would be better served by forming coalitions along class lines, or among various groups of people who are angry at the current mayor, rather than by trying to form a coalition based on racial and ethnic groupings.
"I think that a Democratic strategy for victory in the mayoral race has to involve uniting African-Americans and Latinos with whites in the outer boroughs who are unhappy with Bloomberg and who are upset about taxes and other issues," Mr. Wolfson said. "That is the coalition for victory, and racial polarization hurts that goal." 
Hank Sheinkopf, who is advising Mr. Thompson, said he also believed that the economy, rather than identity politics, would drive the next mayoral election. "There is a legitimacy of a racial coalition," he said, adding, "There are less ethnic politics and more borough politics right now. People in New York City tend to vote for people who are a lot like them, but they also want people of substance."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Quest for Infinite Youth Raises Hopes and Cash

BYLINE:  By ROBERT H. BINSTOCK; Robert H. Binstock, professor of aging, health and society at Case Western Reserve University, is co-editor of the forthcoming book "The Fountain of Youth: Cultural, Scientific, and Ethical Perspectives on a Biomedical Goal."

 BODY:
MERCHANTS OF IMMORTALITY
Chasing the Dream of Human Life Extension
By Stephen S. Hall
439 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $25.
 A year ago an international group of biologists who conduct research on the processes of aging published a consensus statement in Scientific American proclaiming that there is "no truth to the fountain of youth." They did so in order to distinguish themselves from charlatans and quacks who purvey anti-aging products and treatments that are ineffective and sometimes harmful. Yet many legitimate scientists, including some who signed the consensus statement, are striving to develop biotechnologies that will slow or arrest aging and restore and rejuvenate damaged and aging body components. 
 In "Merchants of Immortality" the journalist Stephen S. Hall provides a fascinating, accurate and accessible account of some of these contemporary efforts to combat aging. He concentrates on two arenas of research and development, cell replication and stem cell therapy, and on the commercial and political forces that shape them. Of course neither arena literally involves the goal of achieving immortality.
Mr. Hall begins with the biologist Leonard Hayflick's important discovery that human cells replicate only a finite number of times. Subsequent research by others focused on telomerase, an enzyme that might possibly be used to enable cells to replicate well beyond what had become known as the Hayflick Limit.
This vision motivated Michael West, a biologist, entrepreneur and publicist extraordinaire, to raise venture capital to exploit telomerase's commercial potential. In 1992, appropriating the Greek word for old man, he established Geron, the first biotechnology company explicitly devoted to the molecular biology of aging. Mr. West's dream was to clone telomerase, the "immortalizing enzyme," for potential application in substantially extending cell life and maybe the lives of humans.
Eventually Geron scientists were able to insert the telomerase gene into laboratory cultures of human cells, which then replicated dozens (and eventually hundreds) of times beyond the Hayflick Limit. The stock market responded enthusiastically in the short run by bidding up shares of Geron. But as Mr. Hall points out, extending the lives of cells is a long way from extending the life span of humans.
Disappointingly he leaves the cell replication story here without providing much of an assessment of where the promises and limitations of applying telomerase lie today. Instead he turns to a second story, the science, economics and politics of efforts to develop stem cells for therapeutic purposes. The connective tissue between the two tales is Michael West. By the late 1990's he was eased out of Geron and became the chief executive of Advanced Cell Technology, a company that was attempting to clone embryonic stem cells.
Scientists are not focused on these cells as a potential means of slowing or arresting the basic biological processes of aging but rather because of their tremendous potential for extending years of healthy and vigorous life by treating a wide variety of diseases and regenerating damaged parts of the body. As Mr. Hall notes, they are "pluripotent." Yet the therapeutic payoff from embryonic stem cells will not be achieved without a great deal of further research and development. 
Because of this Mr. Hall weighs in heavily to document and deplore the strong opposition to using embryonic tissue, mobilized by anti-abortion advocates and conservative politicians who share and support their views, as well as by bioethicists who warn that unchecked biotechnology will ultimately destroy the "natural" human virtues.
President Bush's announcement in 2001 of a compromise policy was a critical event in the national controversy over whether the federal government should finance research based on embryonic stem cell cloning. It limited federal research support to those cell lines that existed at the time of his speech. The president claimed that there were more than 60 of them in existence, and that they would be sufficient. Mr. Hall harshly criticizes this claim because, as it turned out, "the number of usable and available stem cell lines is no more than three or four," a woefully inadequate number to enable much research progress.
The consequence, Mr. Hall laments, is that harnessing the enormous potential of embryonic stem cells to alleviate disease and misery is for now a task that has been relegated "to a handful of underfinanced, understaffed and scientifically overwhelmed boutique biotech companies." He concludes, "Constricting our biomedical opportunities in the face of speculative and often ideologically inspired fears is timid, reactive and bad public policy."
Meanwhile efforts to slow and combat aging are proceeding on many other fronts. For instance it is well established that restriction of caloric intake in experimental animals substantially increases their life span and slows aging-associated changes. Respected scientists are trying to develop for humans a pill that mimics the biochemical effects of caloric restriction while still allowing normal food consumption. One of them estimates that success in this undertaking would produce 90-year-olds as vigorous as today's 50-year-olds and increase both average life expectancy and maximum life span by 40 percent. 
The implications of widespread access to such an intervention are profound. Virtually every social institution would be radically transformed.
Scientists and entrepreneurs will persist in their efforts to combat aging as well as disease, with and without government support. It is time for widespread, sustained and farsighted public dialogue about the implications of finding the fountain of youth, so we can take a hand in shaping our collective future. Mr. Hall's compelling book is an excellent launching pad.

HEADLINE: Children Are Getting Fatter, U.S. Finds 

BYLINE:  By ERIC NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
An annual government report that assesses the well-being of American children is warning for the first time that excess weight in childhood poses a major public health problem.
 The report, released last week by the Federal Interagency Forum on Child and Family Statistics, chronicles major changes in weight patterns. From 1976 to 1980, it said, 6 percent of children ages 6 to 18 were overweight. From 1999 to 2000, 15 percent were. 
 "The thing that's kind of alarming here is the amount of change in a relatively short time," Dr. Duane Alexander, National Institute of Child Health and Human Development director, said in an interview. Government officials cited lack of exercise and poor diet as likely causes of the problem.
Although the broad-ranging report has been issued for seven years, this is the first time that it included statistics about weight. Until now, officials said, annual data were insufficient to assess the issue. The report also draws on a wide swath of health, education, housing and other statistics.
In general, the report gave an upbeat assessment about the well-being of American children. Infant mortality, for example, continued to decrease from its high of 10.9 deaths per thousand births in 1993, although the percentage of babies with low birth weights increased slightly, to 7.7. In 2000, the infant mortality rate was 6.9 deaths per 1,000 births. Deaths in childhood, from causes like car crashes and violent crime, also declined.
Births among adolescents also continued to go down, with the greatest reduction among black teenagers. The birthrate among 15- to 17-year-olds in 2001 was 25 per 1,000, the lowest ever recorded, the report said.
Smoking among teenagers also declined to the lowest levels since officials began collecting data in 1975. Among eighth graders, 5 percent reported smoking daily. The figures were 10 percent for 10th graders and 17 percent for 12th graders.
Dr. Alexander said the findings contradicted a widespread perception that children in the United States were doing worse.
Some critics, however, including the Children's Defense Fund, described the report as too upbeat. Toby Chaudhuri, a spokesman for the group, argued that the government was losing sight of the big picture.
And even Dr. Alexander acknowledged that the data in the report did not reflect the economic downturn of the last few years. "Whether these improvements that we're seeing will hold in harder economic times, people are worried, frankly," he said.

HEADLINE: BOOKS ON HEALTH; 
Disturbing Lessons of Girth

BYLINE:  By John Langone

 BODY:
"Menu for Life: African Americans Get Healthy, Eat Well, Lose Weight and Live Beautifully," by Dr. Otelio S. Randall and Donna Randall. 
Broadway Books, $22.95.
 The statistics that fill this book are not cheery, especially as they relate to African-Americans. For example, the authors reveal that the average black woman today wears a size 2X, one that didn't exist 30 years ago and that corresponds to a 38-inch waistline. 
 On the other hand, the average American woman wears a size 16 and has a 34-inch waist.
There's more here to disturb the weight-conscious. Sixty-six percent of black women are overweight, and 1 in 10 is "morbidly obese," more than 100 pounds overweight. (African-American men don't fare well either. Six in 10 are overweight, and 2 of those 6 are obese.)
"African-Americans, especially women, have come to accept heavier bodies," suggest the authors, a married couple, one a cardiologist, the other a nutrition expert. "Each time the cycle swings back to putting on a few more pounds, we tell ourselves this is not so bad, that it is healthy and right to love our substantial bodies."
The Randalls outline myriad health problems that bedevil overweight African-Americans, explore the variety of historic and economic reasons behind unhealthy eating and offer a well-ordered program of exercise, recipes and tips on ways to avoid "emotional eating." 
"We work to increase our share in the American abundance," they write. "Sometimes, yes, bigger is better. Living big can be something grand and beautiful."
But, they add, the price is high.

HEADLINE: A Desperate Global Scavenger Hunt to Keep AIDS Patients Alive 

BYLINE:  By SHARON LERNER

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR 

 BODY:
Every three months or so, a package from the United States arrives at the small clinic that Dr. Mary Annel operates behind an unmarked door in a run-down neighborhood here.
 The package contains drugs to treat those with H.I.V. But the medications do not come from an official aid program or a pharmaceutical company. Instead, they are leftover drugs, prescribed for American patients, that have been collected and shipped by their doctors, whom Dr. Annel has drawn into a stopgap network that keeps at least some of her patients alive. 
 In El Salvador, the government provides antiretroviral drugs to only a small fraction of the people who need them. As in most of the developing world, a vast majority of people with H.I.V. go untreated. 
Most of Dr. Annel's patients can barely afford to travel to her clinic, let alone pay for the drugs that can cost up to $6,000 a year here.
It is illegal to redistribute these medications within the United States after they have been prescribed. But there are no laws prohibiting their use in El Salvador. Dr. Annel, who is also a nun, has amassed enough medicine to supply 26 of her 130 H.I.V.-positive patients. "As soon as I have six months' worth, I start another patient," she said.
While President Bush used his recent trip to Africa to focus attention on a global initiative that promises $15 billion to fight AIDS, people in poor countries are desperately scavenging for drugs that can suppress the virus.
An estimated 5 percent of people in developing nations who need effective AIDS medications are able to get them, the World Health Organization reports. Even fewer are gaining access to antiretroviral therapy through creative routes forged in desperation.
Though the precise number is impossible to know, thousands of people who would otherwise go without the AIDS drugs now get them from programs that recycle them, from informal networks of doctors who donate them, by traveling across borders to buy relatively low-cost generic copies and on the black market.
Aid for AIDS in Manhattan -- a nonprofit group with branches in Italy, Spain and Switzerland -- collects secondhand drugs after people with H.I.V. switch prescriptions, take a break from medications or die.
Expanding on the informal hand-me-down approach employed by Dr. Annel and other doctors, the group passes these antiretrovirals to more than 500 people with H.I.V. throughout Africa, the Caribbean and Latin America.
Others cross borders to take advantage of discrepancies in drug prices among different countries. A year's worth of antiretroviral drugs now costs $2,000 to $2,200 in South Africa, for instance, while the same regimen can be bought for a mere $300 in neighboring Lesotho and Namibia, where the governments permit the sale of generic copies of the drugs.
"Many people go to these countries to buy drugs at the wholesale distributor," said Marta Darder, coordinator of a campaign to provide access to essential medicines for Doctors Without Borders in Cape Town.
"People don't have anything to lose, so if they have a bit of money, they'll run into the pharmacy and buy what they can afford," Ms. Darder said. "Or they'll receive a box of medicines from a relative and take them for a month or two."
While Doctors Without Borders has authorization from the South African government to use generic medicines bought elsewhere, other groups distribute lower-cost medicine illegally and without oversight.
As a result, a thriving black market has grown around AIDS medicines. Health care workers report illegal sales of antiretroviral drugs left over from clinical trials in the United States, for instance.
"Because patients couldn't afford the other drugs, they've bought these at a cheaper price," Cissy Kityo, a health official in Kampala, Uganda, said in a telephone interview.
Medicine from these sources can keep hopes alive. But health experts are concerned that substandard drug quality and inadequate oversight and education of patients will create serious public health problems.
"The worry is that patients who take these drugs are not being monitored," Dr. Kityo said. "Sometimes they're taking very funny combinations."
More than 17 antiretroviral drugs are now available; therapy usually requires 3 of them. Inappropriate drug combinations or inadequate doses can result in side effects, drug resistance and unfortunate interactions between medications. Of particular concern is the spread of drug resistance, highlighted by a report last week that almost 10 percent of new H.I.V. patients in Europe had drug-resistant strains.
In poor countries, people with AIDS are often forced to choose between bad treatment and no treatment. "And if bad treatment can prolong your life just a few months, to that individual it's worth it," said Daniel Berman, coordinator of Doctors Without Borders' Access to Medicines Campaign in Geneva.
Doctors face related quandaries. Though taking two antiretroviral drugs can breed drug-resistance in the virus and is less effective than a three-drug combination in suppressing the virus, some prescribe this regimen if their patients cannot afford a third drug. Other physicians, like Dr. Annel in El Salvador, struggle with the ethical burden of distributing an inadequate supply of drugs among many needy patients.
Henry Chang, executive director of A.H.F. Global Immunity, a branch of AIDS Healthcare Foundation -- which operates clinics in Honduras, South Africa, Uganda and Ukraine -- questioned the wisdom of using drugs that may not be consistently available.
"This treatment should be lifelong," Dr. Chang said. "I'm not sure that groups donating medications have spent a lot of energy on that side of the equation. If they don't distribute drugs carefully and do it well, they could be doing more harm than good."
In the meantime, Mr. Chang's group is working to minimize drug resistance in poor countries by educating patients and health care workers about the importance of taking medicines consistently and only in prescribed combinations.
The World Health Organization has recently set up a coalition to make antiretrovirals affordable and available and to track resistance.
For their part, the international groups distributing medicines to people with AIDS in poor countries insist that any risk involved with their programs is worth taking.
"There's no guarantee that we can keep the people we serve in treatment, but the alternative is far worse," said Amar Sall, executive director of AIDS Empowerment and Treatment International, a Washington-based group that buys generic drugs in India and distributes them to people with H.I.V. in Africa and the Caribbean. "If we don't give people anything, we know they'll die."
That possibility is never far from the thoughts of Dr. Francoise Ndayishimiye. A physician in Bujumbura, Burundi, Dr. Ndayishimiye has worked with AIDS Empowerment and Treatment International to supply 18 people in Burundi with antiretroviral therapy.
"I am so grateful for the drugs," Dr. Ndayishimiye said. "But there are so many other people in need." Her mother and two cousins have AIDS, but they have been unable to get the medications, she said. Many of her patients with H.I.V., now exceeding two dozen, could benefit from antiretroviral therapy but they are unable to secure it.
And though she is not sick enough yet, Dr. Ndayishimiye said she was also infected with the virus and expected to need the drugs eventually.
Having seen more than 30 friends and relatives die of AIDS, Dr. Ndayishimiye struggles to find the right words when speaking to people unable to get the drugs they need. "We don't have so much to say to them," Dr. Ndayishimiye said. "We tell them just to hope that maybe in the coming days the drugs will be cheaper and that eventually they will get them."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: IRAQ'S ECONOMY; 
New Trade Bank to Extend Credit for Rebuilding

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 21 

 BODY:
The United States-led occupation forces in Iraq announced a new program tonight that would allow Iraqi ministries easier access to credit to buy imported food, commodities, materials and other necessities for reconstruction.
 With Iraq's shattered economy and weakened financial institutions, many foreign companies have been reluctant to sell goods on credit either to the ministries that control public services and most large industries or to independent businesses. 
 The newly established Trade Bank of Iraq will use funds, set aside in accounts held by allied forces and earmarked for reconstruction, to guarantee that the sellers will be paid. According to a decree issued by L. Paul Bremer III, the top civilian administrator in Iraq, the new trade bank will be liable for up to $100 million worth of credit guarantees. Mr. Bremer is head of the Coalition Provisional Authority, the American-led alliance rebuilding Iraq. 
The money backing the bank will come from the $1.2 billion Development Fund for Iraq, said Peter McPherson, a top economic adviser to Mr. Bremer. The development fund is money already being used to help finance the $2.2 billion budget deficit projected for the second half of this year. The trade bank will initially be capitalized with up to $5 million from the development fund. If it is unable to meet its obligations with available cash, the trade bank will be able to consume up to $95 million more from the development fund.
The trade bank, an independent Iraqi governmental agency, will back up guarantees issued by a consortium of banks and financial institutions to sellers of goods and services to Iraqi ministries and businesses. The ministries, remnants of the old government, are now overseen by occupation officials.
In an interview tonight, Mr. McPherson said it was possible that up to $100 million in transactions each month could be made using the trade bank. Private companies could also use the new guarantees, but the businesses would have to post some form of collateral or margin to cover the purchases, he said. 
The new bank will speed the acquisition of materials needed for rebuilding Iraq, including power generators, sewage pipes and oil field equipment.
"The first step that a country in deep distress usually takes to get out of such distress is trade credit," he said.
But the finances of the reconstruction effort remain uncertain, and officials are still grappling with how to find the billions of dollars for the huge projects that are needed just to get Iraq to where it has even marginally acceptable systems for sewage, electricity generation and distribution, and other public services.
As of July 1, the occupation had $5.4 billion available to pay for reconstruction. But that is expected to dwindle to $1.1 billion by the end of the year as the allies burn through cash used to finance the budget deficit and to help the Iraqi Central Bank support its currency. 
Ending the year with $1.1 billion may itself be an optimistic projection, as it depends on Iraq's generating net oil revenues of almost $3.5 billion in the second half of the year. Some oil analysts say that level of revenue may not be possible because of the looting and sabotage that have undermined Iraq's already dilapidated oil-producing infrastructure.
American officials hope a donor conference later this year will raise billions of dollars from other countries to finance specific projects, allowing the coalition to use its limited cash for other purposes.
Companies involved in rebuilding Iraq, including Halliburton and Bechtel, are also pushing a plan to pledge future Iraqi oil and gas revenue to help raise billions for reconstruction. The fate of that plan remains uncertain. It has drawn both supporters and critics within the Bush administration as well as within the new 25-member Iraqi Governing Council, the country's first postwar government.

HEADLINE: Economic Indicators Rise For 3rd Month 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
An index of future economic activity was higher in June for the third consecutive month, a private research group reported yesterday.
 The group, the Conference Board, said its index of leading economic indicators edged up 0.1 percent, reflecting stronger stock prices, an increase in the money supply and more permits for home construction. 
The increase matched economists' forecasts. 
 The index, a broad measure of how the economy is likely to perform in the next three to six months, had risen 1.1 percent in May and 0.1 percent in April. The consecutive increases, though mostly modest ones, mark the longest unbroken gains since January 2002. 
Economists said that the 13 interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve since the start of 2001 and billions of dollars in tax cuts might provide more strength for the economy in the months ahead. Maria Forres of Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson in Chicago, predicted, "The lower tax rates and interest rates will fuel business investment in the second half." 
Four of the 10 indicators that the Conference Board uses to derive the index of leading economic indicators contributed to the rise. A decline in initial jobless claims also buoyed the index.
Measures of the average workweek and new orders for business equipment had no effect on the June results. Factors restraining the index included a drop in consumer goods orders, lower consumer confidence and a narrowing of the spread between the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note and the federal funds rate.
The Conference Board's index of coincident indicators, a gauge of current economic activity, increased 0.1 percent in June for a second month. That index tracks payrolls, incomes, sales and production.
The index of lagging indicators fell 0.5 percent last month, compared with a 0.1 percent decrease in May.

HEADLINE: Shifting Its Focus, Kodak Buys Dental Technology Company 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company, struggling to reinvent itself as digital technology eats into its once-stellar photographic film businesses, said yesterday that it would buy PracticeWorks, a company that sells information technology systems for dental offices, for about $500 million in cash.
 Analysts said the size of the deal was a clear sign that Kodak had finally accepted that health care-related businesses would be the engine of its future growth, supplanting consumer photography, for decades the bedrock of its profits and its image. 
 "Health imaging is probably the one end-market in which Kodak can have nice long-term growth," said David R. Giroux, an investment analyst for T. Rowe Price, which owns Kodak shares.
The analyst gets no argument from Daniel A. Carp, Kodak's chairman. "We are turning from a consumer film company to a balanced company, and we have consistently identified health imaging as an attractive opportunity," Mr. Carp said in an interview. 
Lately, it is one of the few opportunities for the company. The sluggish economy and the migration of photographers toward digital cameras have whittled away at Kodak's sales. Conventional wisdom among analysts is that this year, for the first time, sales of digital cameras will exceed sales of film-based cameras -- a trend that no one, least of all Kodak, expects to see reversed. 
In contrast, societal trends within the United States and around the world bode well for businesses related to delivering health care.
Kodak took its first plunge into the field in 1998 when it bought Imation's medical imaging business, which gave it the technology to capture X-rays digitally and print them without chemicals. Since then, health imaging has provided an increasing share of Kodak's sales and profits, accounting for $2.3 billion of Kodak's total $12.8 billion in revenue last year. 
"Film sales may come back when the economy comes back, but health imaging will still be their biggest growth area," said Ulysses Yannas, an analyst with Buckman, Buckman & Reid. "The PracticeWorks deal is an immediate injection of growth." 
Indeed, even within health imaging, dental offices are a relatively untapped market. Kodak has been an important provider of X-ray film for dental offices for decades, but it has marketed its digital information and archiving services primarily to medical doctors and hospitals, not dentists. Kodak estimates that the annual market for dental imaging systems is about $600 million.
With PracticeWorks, which itself recently bought a French dental imaging company, Trophy Radiologie, Kodak gains the ability to offer dentists a start-to-finish computer system that they can use to schedule patient visits, take digital X-rays, and append them -- either as printouts or electronic files -- to both a patient's charts and to insurance claims. And it lets Kodak learn how dental offices work.
"We'll be in the sweet spot of millions of transactions every day, and we can develop the skills to provide management services as well as tools in the future," said Dan Kerpelman, who Kodak recruited last year from G.E. Medical Systems to head its health imaging business.
Though the deal seemed to take analysts by surprise, Mr. Kerpelman said in an interview that it was long in the making. Kodak had put out feelers to PracticeWorks and Trophy before they merged in December. Since then, he said, Kodak got to know executives at both companies, a fact Mr. Kerpelman said should ease the integration process. 
"We did lots of due diligence, we've test-driven the relationships with the people, and we know that this is a tight strategic fit," he said. The deal probably will not close until the end of the year, Mr. Kerpelman said, but an acquisition integration team is already up and running. 
The price was high. Kodak will pay the equivalent of $21.50 a share for PracticeWorks common stock and $7.33 a share for preferred shares, and will assume $34 million in debt. Kodak expects PracticeWorks to add $215 million to revenue in the first year after the deal closes. But Mr. Kerpelman conceded that the deal would probably dilute earnings slightly for the next couple of years. 
PracticeWorks will keep its headquarters in Atlanta, while Trophy will remain based in Paris, and Kodak anticipates few job cuts. "The synergies are in the growth side, so we have no need to slash and burn," Mr. Kerpelman said. 
Although Kodak says it has plenty of cash to pay for the acquisition, analysts worry about the opportunity cost. After a hastily arranged conference call yesterday to discuss the deal, several analysts expressed concern that Kodak would begin paying down its debts more slowly, and may even reduce its dividend. (On that subject, Mr. Carp would say only that Kodak's dividend policy would be reviewed as usual at a board meeting in September.)
Investors clearly think PracticeWorks shareholders got the better deal. Shares of PracticeWorks, which have been climbing since the fall, gained another $3.53 yesterday to close at $21.21, up 20 percent. Kodak shares, which have been sliding for a month, closed at $25.40, down 90 cents or 3.4 percent. 
"The deal is right strategically," Mr. Giroux of T. Rowe Price said, "but the price is still very aggressive for what they are getting."

HEADLINE: House Leaders Delay AmeriCorps Action 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21 

 BODY:
Facing a majority of House members in favor of emergency spending for AmeriCorps, House Republican leaders who oppose the increase for the program decided today to put off a floor confrontation. 
 Supporters said they believed that a cash infusion would arrive soon, after a compromise with the Senate. 
 AmeriCorps, the national service program, is facing a cash crisis, and it has warned of drastic cuts to popular initiatives like Teach for America, City Year and Save the Children if Congress does not appropriate $100 million in a few weeks. In New York, the financing would be cut by 68 percent and the number of volunteers who receive stipends would be reduced, to 599 from 1,959. Nationwide, 20,000 out of 50,000 positions would be eliminated, AmeriCorps officials said.
"Here we are in the middle of a recession, and there are no jobs out there," said Representative Norman D. Dicks, Democrat of Washington. "Why would we do this to volunteers right now?" 
Mr. Dicks sponsored an amendment adding the $100 million that was defeated tonight by the appropriations committee in a party line vote. 
The Senate recently voted 71 to 21 to add $100 million for the program to a $1.9 billion spending bill for disaster appropriations.

HEADLINE: NYC; 
In New York, Anniversaries Are Abundant

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
PERHAPS the most astonishing aspect of Central Park's 150th anniversary is that New York City threw a giant party to celebrate something done by the State Legislature.
 Albany honored downstate! It wasn't quite a "when pigs fly" idea, but it came awfully close, ranking with the Mets beating Atlanta, Leona Helmsley taking a vow of poverty and Donald Rumsfeld acknowledging fallibility. In short, it was an idea hovering at the outer edges of the possible, not something on which to bet the farm. 
 Yet over the weekend, it happened. By the many thousands, New Yorkers took part in festivities commemorating the day in 1853 -- the actual date was July 21, yesterday -- when the Legislature authorized the city to use its power of eminent domain to set aside land for a large, central park. 
There was much to celebrate. The park is New York's secular cathedral.
The celebration did make one wonder, though, why yesterday was designated the birthday. The date of conception seemed more like it. The birth, one could argue, did not come until 1858, when Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux produced their designs. Perhaps an even better candidate is 1859, when the park was opened to the public. Why not wait another five or six years for the party?
That's easy, said Regina S. Peruggi, president of the Central Park Conservancy. The legislative action in 1853 was "a visionary moment," she said yesterday. Without it, there would have been no park.
Sounds reasonable. So let's move on.
With all the hoopla over the park, some noteworthy New York anniversaries have not been getting their due. Not that every one has been overlooked. Far from it. Admirable attention has been paid to the fact that in the New York of 1853, Henry Steinway began producing his pianos and Elisha Graves Otis introduced his safety elevator.
But perhaps more than the sound of one hand clapping is in order for other events of 1853. That is when New York passed the first truancy law. According to Chase's Calendar of Events, a compendium of assorted factoids, parents were fined $50 if their children did not go to school.
FIFTY dollars was no doubt a great deal of money 150 years ago. If the city were to enforce a similar policy now -- no need to call it a ticket blitz -- inflation-adjusted truancy fines alone might go far to reduce the budget deficit.
Similarly given short shrift is the 1853 opening of a New York clinic for poor women and children. That was the work of Elizabeth Blackwell, the first woman to earn a medical degree in the United States.
But for neglect of a great New York moment, does anything beat the lack of cheering for the potato chip, invented 150 years ago this summer in Saratoga Springs?
As the story goes, George Crum, an American Indian chef in the upstate resort town, was having trouble pleasing a finicky diner who wanted French fries (as a certain kind of potato was known before freedom fries came along). Exasperated, Crum threw into the cooking oil some potatoes that he had cut paper thin, figuring the diner would hate them. He guessed wrong. If not for that mistake, we moderns might not be blessed with the crinkly bags carrying all those "nutrition facts" on the back.
Was that a big moment, or what? But you don't hear much about it, any more than we are told about some great events of 100 years ago.
Yes, we've heard plenty about the Williamsburg Bridge having been opened in 1903. But why do we overlook that, in the same year in New York, the ultimate barbershop quartet song, "Sweet Adeline," was performed publicly for the first time? It had music by Harry Armstrong and words by Richard Gerard, who later said that he had been inspired by a young woman working behind the music counter of a New York department store.
In 1903, the first World Series was played, with the Red Sox of Boston defeating the Pirates of Pittsburgh. This is an important milestone for New York because that Series led inexorably to George Steinbrenner's habitual tormenting of Yankees' players and managers.
And how can we not note that this year is the centennial of the first traffic cops in New York? Rule books then advised police officers on speed limits, right-of-way priorities and the like. For safety, passenger vehicles were permitted to go no faster than 8 miles per hour.
It just goes to show how much can change in the course of century. Eight miles an hour? Today, on Manhattan's crowded streets, that practically qualifies as a breakneck speed.
