HEADLINE: Let There Be Light 

BYLINE:  By Richard Eder; Richard Eder writes book reviews and articles for The Times.

 BODY:
 EVIDENCE OF
THINGS UNSEEN
By Marianne Wiggins.
383 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $25.
 Ray Foster first sees Opal upside down, a shimmering reflection in the iridescent glass bubble that swirls at the tip of her father's blowpipe. A self-taught science adept, Fos has been driving through a hard rain to the North Carolina shore to count shooting stars for a home-brewed hypothesis about light. His truck sputters and dies outside the glass workshop. Sturdy, right side up and no longer shimmering, Opal marches out, opens the hood, dries the magneto and gets the engine going.
Shooting stars and iridescence, and a wiped-down engine. They are among the counterings of soul and body, of immortal longings and mortal contrivance, in one of the most suggestively original love stories in our current fiction. These pairings serve a broader design as well, one that runs from World War I to the development of the atomic bomb. They stand as the moral poles of an individual, for whom tinkering American idealism is gradually flattened by the impersonal weight of technology and economic concentration.
Marianne Wiggins has written something approaching an epic, and it could have been dangerous. She is a writer who takes wild risks of style and story. She gets where she's going by going too far, and that can mean going too far the wrong way. 
Her novel "John Dollar" was a rending, mesmerizing novel of eight girls marooned on an island. Its beauty left its readers all the more defenseless against its horror. There was a splendid short-story collection, "Herself in Love." Two more recent novels -- written a few years after a fatwa-forced existence hiding out with Salman Rushdie, then her husband -- claimed sweeping imaginative territory, but made awkward if fitfully brilliant efforts to occupy it.
There is roughness in "Evidence of Things Unseen," an occasional grandiloquent reach beyond its fictional grasp. Rarely, you sense Wiggins spurring her story to lift it to the next stage, or chivying a sentence to snare a sublimity. This time, though, she has schooled her winged horse to transport human riders.
Even with their epic stirrings her characters are wryly, plangently particular. When their voices soar, it is from the grit of country speech. The journey of Fos and Opal through America's 1920's, 30's and 40's is up and down and eventually downhill, matching the author's sense of the course taken by our national virtues. But it is a discursive, resilient descent; one that arouses in the reader, along with sadness over what is being lost, exhilaration that it ever existed.
Fos begins in 1918 as one of a bunch of North Carolina recruits in the American Expeditionary Force in France. They went "for valor, decency and hell like they'd never known." With no detectable join, Wiggins merges this Appalachian twang with something darker and larger. "Not one among them who survived was proud of it in any way that didn't cast a shadow back across his pride." 
Light, Fos volunteers when recruiters ask what he is good at. His untutored passion, speculative and mystical, is for starlight, phosphorescent plankton, lightning bugs, radium: natural, not man-made, illumination. Naturally, since the shortest military distance is a broken line, two British officers "with more brass than a church organ between them" (twang again) put him in a workshop making fireworks and colored flares to light up the trenches. "So that the boys could see what they were shooting at. See death coming, when it came."
Fos's wartime friendship with the unit's photographer, nicknamed Flash, leads to partnership in a photography business in Knoxville. When he's not working in the studio he tours county fairs, putting on fireworks displays and letting customers examine the bones of their feet in his portable X-ray machine. His passion, though, is tinkering with notions about phosphorescence; in particular the thought that it increases when the night sky is at its brightest. 
Thus the trip to the coast, timed to the Perseid meteor shower. His truck, with a sign reading "Phenomenologist" (he figures it ought to mean someone who investigates phenomena), carries the X-ray machine and a jar of fireflies whose performance is to be measured at the height of the shooting-star display.
Nature has other things than light, though. It has rain, and it has love. Fos had left this last to Flash, an exuberant woman-chaser, while he chased his scientific speculations. Opal changes all that. Their wet meeting at the truck, she wiping, he noticing, she noticing his noticing; also, accidental brushings of arms, a loose button and a Perseid shower of casually exploratory yet charged remarks: these ensnare the reader almost as thoroughly as the couple. We do not so much read as eavesdrop.
In a few hours Fos and Opal are lying on the beach in Kitty Hawk, where lovemaking mingles with star counting. She works as a bookkeeper, so she does the counting. She is the practical one, he the awkward celestial idealist; and the distinction runs through the book even while periodically dissolving. He's been out in the world and seen a war; by contrast to her crimped small-town life, he offers a welcome if drifty openness. "As much as she was headstrong, single-minded and self-made, she could see a vision of herself taking shape in Fos's eyes that she liked better."
Fos marries Opal and takes her to Knoxville. It is a while before she and Flash can be comfortable with each other. She is serious and he is a tearaway, but he comes to recognize the radiance in her solemnity, and she the pain (he has broken with his family: rich, bigoted and the town's aristocrats) in his wildness. A triangle of loyalty and trust takes shape. There is work (her practical talents revive the photography shop), picnics, rowing and fishing on the river, and afternoons of talk.
The idyll doesn't last but, through tragedy and transformation, the three figures somehow do. Disasters accumulate. Flash is jailed after getting a young girl in fatal trouble. Opal and Fos's life collapses; they leave town to take over the farm of a cousin crushed by the deaths of his wife and child. Neither has any idea how to manage. At night, hardly able to speak, they can only hold each other.
Then the new Tennessee Valley Authority hires Fos to talk up electrification at county fairs, and later to document rural life in Walker Evans-style photographs. Progress has rescued them -- at a progressively mortal price. Dams submerge the farm; they move to housing and jobs at the Oak Ridge atomic bomb project, set up on vast tracts of T.V.A. land.
Their lives, once shaped by their quirks, dreams and contrivances, are subject here to a chilly regimentation. Science, which for tinkering Fos means the exploration of spirit and possibilities, serves here a lethal purposefulness. Lethal to both of them as well, in a fashion too splendidly and paradoxically intricate -- as are so many of the book's other movements -- to detail. Years later, in a kind of epilogue, their orphaned son will go on a quest for them. It is a quest for a lost America.
If satire is what closed Saturday, saga, in modern times, is what sags like Thanksgiving's balloon giants. Wiggins keeps hers aloft, for the most part, with potent, well-aimed jets of breath: the lifting jerk and veer of agile human moments.
The patch of moisture that appears on a lab worker's gauze mask when he speaks. Opal, rowed on the river, registering the creaking oarlocks as if she were "being lofted by the ball and socket action in the wings of a giant bird." A bereaved farmer with the expression seen "in certain kinds of people of an iron reserve who never cry. They end up looking like they've cried too much." Flash, out of prison, holding to a salvific memory from the guilty catastrophe that put him there: "A lover's gaze is like having your portrait painted by a master and then being able to look into it, stare at it for as long as the love lasts -- or for the rest of your life."
A half-dozen years ago, two of our masters experimented with panoramic novels: Philip Roth with "American Pastoral" and John Updike with "In the Beauty of the Lilies." Wiggins lacks their mastery, their agility, their breadth and craft. Yet I find in "Evidence of Things Unseen" an urgency they lack, a passion to hurl herself into a continental unknown, to seek, misstep, recover and push on, while noticing every grass blade along the way, that seems to me the mark of a true epic endeavor.

HEADLINE: THE LAST WORD; 
Pattern Recognition

BYLINE:  By Laura Miller 

 BODY:
Feeling alienated from contemporary architecture is a commonplace experience: the pleasure that leaches out of your afternoon stroll when you have to walk along a big building with a flat, smooth, featureless front; bafflement at another magazine spread celebrating a conglomeration of soul-less boxes. So it's surprising that social critics (besides the ever-canny Tom Wolfe) haven't had more of a field day with the topic. In this underfought war, there's even a ready-made hero in the person of Christopher Alexander, an architect who was born in Vienna, raised in England and now lives in California, and is something of a prophet without honor in his own profession. 
 Alexander produces the kind of books every serious reader should wrestle with once in a while: fat, challenging, grandiose tracts that encourage you to take apart the way you think and put it back together again. Depending on whom you talk to, they're either canonical or completely off the reservation; among architects, he has some devoted followers and plenty of scornfully dismissive critics, particularly among the champions of the avant-garde. "A Pattern Language" and "The Timeless Way of Building," two seminal works he wrote with five colleagues, have continued to sell well since they were first published in the 1970's, but despite his position as emeritus professor of architecture at the University of California, Berkeley, their influence on his profession (outside the continuation of some of his ideas in the New Urbanism movement) has faded. Instead, laypeople use "A Pattern Language" to design their own homes, and "The Timeless Way of Building" has been a major influence on, of all things, a school of software engineering called object-oriented programming. 
 Even people who aren't building a house or constructing a database are fascinated by "A Pattern Language," a recipe book of "patterns," or archetypal elements that can be combined to form a structure as small as a desk or sitting area or as large as a city or region. The patterns, distilled from (mostly premodernist) examples all over the world, are what the authors believe best foster the comfort, activities and social lives of the people who live in them. To use a key Alexander word, these patterns help make a building "alive." The book is easiest to digest if you read its 253 numbered sections in reverse order, from smallest to largest, since most of the thinking on regional and urban planning reflects the starry-eyed utopianism of its day: nice, but wildly impractical, politically and economically. Some of the more nuts-and-bolts patterns, however, have become architectural rules of thumb: "Balconies and porches that are less than six feet deep are hardly ever used"; "When they have a choice, people will always gravitate to those rooms that have light on two sides." In a profession that seems indifferent to the concerns and delights of ordinary life, Alexander has always been a humanist, a proponent of window seats, sunny spots and arcades.
Last year, Alexander began the publication of "The Nature of Order," his four-volume magnum opus, the second volume of which appears next month. An unclassifiable work, "The Nature of Order" offers the results of his quest to figure out what underlying principles make his patterns work. It has some of the same qualities that make "The Timeless Way of Building" and parts of "A Pattern Language" a tricky sell to hardheaded empiricists wary of any whiff of the metaphysical. Clearly influenced by Taoism, Alexander unabashedly uses words like "wholeness"and complains of the prevailing Cartesian "mechanistic" view of the universe. "The Nature of Order" has vast ambitions; it floats a hypothesis that Alexander hopes will lead to "a new view of space and matter" and to a different conception of "the fundamentals of the way the world is made." This theory, very crudely summarized, would be based on the understanding that order is inherent in space and systems and that they are more or less "alive" based on the quality of the order they manifest.
That precis alone is probably enough to send some readers fleeing to the new Janet Evanovich novel, but it would be stupid and shortsighted to write Alexander off as a fuzzy-minded New Age philosopher. He did leave me unpersuaded that what he calls "life" is a property of the physical universe, but I am convinced, after reading the first two volumes of "The Nature of Order," that at the very least, "order" as he meticulously defines it is fundamental to human cognition, which makes it important enough. Besides, as with all of Alexander's writings, "The Nature of Order" is so firmly grounded in the visual, palpable world that it can never be accused of drifting off into cloud-cuckoo-land. And then there's his unsettling tendency to be right.
TO make his case, Alexander repeatedly uses a flexible and eloquent tool: he presents two images -- a pair of buildings or drawings or household objects or country roads -- and asks the viewer to choose the one that has the most "life." (Sometimes he asks which one is "a better picture of the self.") The quintessential pairing asks people to choose between a diner-style saltshaker and a bottle of the best-known brand of ketchup. According to Alexander, 80 percent of the people asked choose the saltshaker, and his experiments with other pairings along these lines yield similar results; when asked to pick which of two images looks most "right" in some vague way, a great majority of respondents gravitate to one -- which does make you wonder if the question really is as vague as it seems. Even if it's hard to agree with Christopher that a science comparable to physics can be created out of such responses, following his argument amounts to being shown how to see art and the world by a man with one of the most developed senses of beauty I've ever encountered. In wending my way through his image-packed books, I found myself looking harder at photographs -- of Turkish carpets, Moroccan mosaics, Japanese temples, ginkgo leaves, soap bubbles, postmodern houses, you name it -- than I have looked at anything in a long time. Afterward, I saw familiar objects and places with new eyes -- not as momentous as a new science, I'll grant you, but a revelation all the same.
